commit_message:
Move bandit into pep8

The non-voting bandit job is running stable, let's make it voting now.

Run security linter bandit as part of pep8. Pep8 is the usual linter
target and thus let's use it there instead of starting another node for
this short-running job.

Change-Id: Ia6183592f4623e62b1882b2ee549ba3c35f823fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-magnumclient refs/changes/04/284404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use yaml.safe_load() instead of yaml.load()

yaml.load() provides the ability to construct an arbitrary python object
that may be dangerous. yaml.safe_load() limits this ability to simple
python objects like integers or lists.

ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YAML#Security

Change-Id: Ic8313b4042aad1e077ba1fbb68979f8745adfe3d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/93/280693/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revise trust_id param for sdk connection

trust_id parameter is now transmitted to sdk driver as a UUID string
rather than a list of UUID. This change is to keep compatible with
Juno environment.

Change-Id: I2fff2b3b5979fc26fcb86170e27211f3688a31ef

commit_message:
Convert warnings to errors for local builds

For local builds, call sphinx-build directly with -W
rather than assuming pbr works correctly.

Change-Id: Ic9ecddc7b54529dbf23900a3fde871de454b9b8d

commit_message:
make event-alarm supported in default

Alarming function in ceilometer code base will be removed in Mitaka,
and Aodh, which has event-alarm feature, should be enabled in default
configuration. So, we can assume CEILOMETER_EVENT_ALARM=True and add
the required configuration to 'event_pipeline.yaml.

To avoid MQ flooding with no consumer, this patch makes devstack
disable this configuration if 'aodh-listener' isn't enabled.

This can reduce complexity of packaging.

Change-Id: Id2d0fdf757568f16b0f63ee4df74f55796a7e9cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/32/273432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CEILOMETER_EVENT_ALARM=${CEILOMETER_EVENT_ALARM:-True}

commit_message:
Update documentation for running tests

The documentation for how to run tests currently says to use
"python setup.py test", which results in errors. Update the docs
to specify tox.

Change-Id: Ib32f6c0708de9439b6bdee4a4fb56cb88bc47d5a
Closes-Bug: #1550068
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/97/284997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Run tests with ``tox -e py27`` if running with python 2.7. See the ``tox.ini`` file for other test environment options.

commit_message:
run_tests: generate testrepository.subunit all the time

Make sure testrepository.subunit file is generated whether tempest
failure or success.

It will help to provide actual results on
http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health

(without that patch, we only have success jobs)

Change-Id: Iaa7f9f3434d75bdf1dbf605b1b520a97a0131df8

commit_message:
Remove unneeded glance unit test assert calls

The glance_store library now accepts a verifier object for use with
verifying signatures, as a result of a recently merged patch [1].
There are some glance unit tests that do not expect this verifier
object to be passed to the add method of glance_store, and will
therefore fail with a new release of the glance_store library.

This patch removes the assert lines for the tests that will fail,
since it is not necessary for glance to test glance_store in that
way at the glance level.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/183110/

Change-Id: I404fbc40dafa159a63a6dfee563f05ee80c073dc
Partial-Bug: #1516031
(cherry picked from commit eab1567d48a18fa968c7b66c3641dd037da1f84e)

-- squashed with another change to get liberty working --

Remove glance_store specific unit tests

TestStoreAddToBackend contains a set of tests that should belong to
the glance_store. Recently, these tests were about to break
glance as they mocked internal methods. Those mocks were
removed in commit eab1567d48a18fa968c7b66c3641dd037da1f84e.

The tests are added back to glance_store in
change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/273786.

Conflicts:
        glance/tests/unit/test_store_image.py

Closes-Bug: #1548902

Depends-On: I688629d37e9146aef33fbc9bb6fd8780521e06ab
Change-Id: Ic67826a4d02cb30cc429a3d4abc46d6ca96f31ad
(cherry picked from commit 1ebbfd3dc1694dc4f26e763da9eee833bb5d2545)

commit_message:
Simplify filter for expensive jobs

After renaming a networking-ovn job for consistency,
replace 'networking-ovn' with 'install' in filter to
prevent patches such as documentation from triggering
expensive jobs. In this particular case, prevent the
'gate-install-dsvm-networking-ovn-kuryr-nv' job from
running.

Change-Id: I518bab798dcca0b681172c27db126d147f1b88cf

commit_message:
Fix collision with update and update cancel

"openstack update" collides/hides with "openstack update cancel"

I discussed a few possible solutions in the bug report.
Will change to have a new "openstack stack cancel" command
and it will cancel the pending action, for now just supporting
update.

Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient

Change-Id: I7e054ecffea5b03a815f69515651e9c377ff68c2
Closes-Bug: #1545131

components on an OpenStack installation.

added_lines: .. Copyright 2014-2015 OpenStack Foundation All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. =============== Getting Started =============== Once manual installation of tacker components are completed, follow the below steps to get started with tacker and validate the installation. i). Create a sample-vnfd.yml file with the following content: .. code-block:: ini template_name: sample-vnfd description: demo-example service_properties: Id: sample-vnfd vendor: tacker version: 1 vdus: ..vdu1: id: vdu1 vm_image: <IMAGE> instance_type: <FLAVOR> network_interfaces: management: network: <NETWORK_ID> management: true placement_policy: availability_zone: nova auto-scaling: noop config: param0: key0 param1: key1 .. ii). Create a sample vnfd. .. code-block:: console tacker vnfd-create --name <NAME> --vnfd-file sample-vnfd.yml .. iii). Create a VNF. .. code-block:: console tacker vnf-create --name <NAME> --vnfd-id <VNFD_ID> .. iv). Check the status. .. code-block:: console tacker vnf-list tacker vnf-show <VNF_ID> ..

commit_message:
Use pymysql database driver for OpenStack DBs

PyMySQL is a new driver introduced in Liberty.
This patch change the MySQL url to use mysql+pymysql like recommanded.

commit_message:
Make AutoScale sub-template a string instead of map

To avoid the InvalidTemplateReference exception when resolving
get_resource functions for resources that are in the sub-template but
not the parent template.

commit_message:
Change requirements.txt to use older version of oslo.context

A new release of Oslo.context was added Feb. 25. It breaks some of
Barbican's unit tests. This is a temporary fix to move things along
in the gate. In the future all the unit tests which fail
because of this must be editted.

Change-Id: I46fd03114f9ef6073709815407e221e1db4c1d1b

commit_message:
Fix translation setup

This patch adds 'senlin_dashboard' into the list of INSTALLED_APPS so
that the .pot files under the 'senlin_dashboard/locale' directory will
work. In future, we may need to remove the 'senlin_dashboard.cluster'
entry.

Change-Id: If5479865aea55b271ed13a4c5aa2cf0245d49963

commit_message:
Defaults are ignored with flake8

If “ignore” is not set under flake8 in the tox.ini
file there there are defaults set to be ignored.

The depended patch fixes many of the problems.

Change-Id: Ieed2fe1c4654e201d3fe6d40ef93e247ee736f8b
Doc: http://flake8.readthedocs.org/en/latest/config.html#default
Depends-On: I935ab48e7c5bac5f88ecdb3a05f73fb44fc9f41d
Closes-Bug: #1548910

commit_message:
InstanceGroup to keep FAILED resources in template

Modify the InstanceGroup (and, by extension, Heat and AWS
AutoscalingGroup) types to give members in a FAILED state the highest
priority for being removed when scaling down or being updated in
a rolling update. Currently, FAILED resources are omitted when building
a new template for the scaling group, so any such resources would never
be replaced by one of the same name. This change will allow for
continuity of naming in the case of a change that doesn't permanently
remove the resource due to scaling down.

Change-Id: I8fe93869dfbe4c4de6c48a65aeef0f71355eaf46
Partially-implements: blueprint mark-unhealthy

commit_message:
Restrict ansible version to avoid empty hosts exception

Ansible 2.0.1.0 will raise AnsibleError in adhoc mode
if provided hosts list is empty, in previous version,
it will only give warnings.  We don't want to ansible
to raise error because it will break "gate_hook" for
3rd party CI which is not running nodepool.

Change-Id: I5d9376202709f1e810c4f69e61e7f515f2adbfef
Closes-Bug: #1549688

commit_message:
Add python-pytun

This library is needed for tests in dragonflow. python-pytun[1] is used to
interface (read packets from and send packets to) TAP (and TUN) devices.

The package is actively maintained. Its license is MIT.

Change-Id: Ie94af1a2fbab102d82c96d316613f44ea22fabed

commit_message:
Add process monitoring for Octavia

This change creates a octavia detection plugin and adds process
monitoring for octavia-api, octavia-worker, octavia-health-manager
and octavia-housekeeping processes.

Change-Id: I71411c640713ac0ab2b3bbb332dfab064b08379b

commit_message:
Add process monitor for StrongSwan "charon" process

The neutron-vpnaas service uses the StrongSwan IPSec implementation
and it always expects the "charon" process to exist.  To avoid
redundancy, this is specified as "ipsec/charon".

Change-Id: I68acede827bd8583803be0ec8edd0ef9c3585df6

commit_message:
Uploading volume to specific image

Currently, in uploading volume to image,
cinder will create a new image and upload the data.
For Glance V2 api, users may have created a image first,
and then upload volume to this image.

For this purpose, Cinder may add a option param '--image_id'
to specify a existing and empty image to upload volume.

This will enhance the flexibility to this operation.

Implements: blueprint uploading-volume-to-specific-image
Change-Id: I923c2aabb89c9e2bdf706957457333e99fdf72fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/10/258310/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Uploading volume to specific image ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/uploading-volume-to-specific-image Support to upload volume to a specific image. Problem description =================== Currently, in uploading volume to image, cinder will create a new image and upload the data. For Glance V2 api, users may have created a image first, and then upload volume to this image. For this purpose, Cinder may add a option param '--image_id' to specify a existing and empty image to upload volume. This will enhance the flexibility to this operation. Use Cases ========= When users create a new and empty image by using Glance v2 api, they can set some image attribute as they want, like 'protected', 'visibility', or 'property'. After creation, users can specify this image to upload the data from volume. This will help users to customize images flexibly working with Cinder. Proposed change =============== * Add option param '--image_id' in uploading volume to image. * Cinder api make sure that image is empty and then using this image to upload data from volume. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Add option param '--image_id' in uploading volume to image: Cinder upload-to-image volume_id image_name --image_id xxx Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: wanghao<wanghao749@huawei.com> Work Items ---------- * Implement code in Cinder API. * Update cinderclient to support this function. * Add change to API doc. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Both unit and Tempest tests need to be created to cover the code change that mentioned in "Proposed change". Documentation Impact ==================== 1. The cinder API documentation will need to be updated to reflect the REST API changes. References ========== None

commit_message:
Resource mark unhealthy RPC and ReST API

There may exist resources that the user (or application) knows are
unhealthy where Heat has no way of determining that.

Add a PATCH handler to the Resource endpoint::

  /stacks/<stack_name>/<stack_id>/resources/<resource_id>

The PATCH method will accept a JSON body of the form::

  {
    'mark_unhealthy': <bool>,
    'resource_status_reason': <string>
  }

This patch Implements:
- RPC API to mark resources as CHECK_FAILED in both the legacy and
convergence architectures in heat-engine
- ReST front end to the RPC API call in heat-api

Change-Id: Ifa48b179723a2100fff548467db9e162bc669d13
Partially-implements: blueprint mark-unhealthy

commit_message:
implement sending health notifications

this change implements sending notifications about
health check creation and updates. code was refactored
to avoid duplicated code.

Partially-implements blueprint: cluster-verification

Change-Id: Iac74a7bdec0f59a3720e17a682268faea36a45f3

commit_message:
Enable the Load Balancer v2 for the Ceilometer(Part Two)

In this change set, add the new methods to collect the new meters
in the LBaaS v2[1].

list_listener: list all the listeners
list_loadbalancer: list all the loadbalancers
get_loadbalancer_stats : get the statistics of the specified
loadbalancer.

[1]https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/LBaaS/API_2.0

Co-Authored-By: Xia Linjuan <ljxiash@cn.ibm.com>
DocImpact: new metrics are introduced
Change-Id: I982f28917d1f8fd3d4352037f8832de9ef869942
Implements: blueprint lbaas-v2-enablement

'3e4d8bec50a845fcb09e03a4375c691d', 'protocol_port': 80, 'operating_status': 'PENDING_CREATE'} ] def test_listener_get_samples(self): samples = list(self.pollster.get_samples( self.manager, {}, self.assertEqual(set(['network.services.lb.loadbalancer']), set([s.name for s in samples])) def test_loadbalancer_discovery(self): discovered_loadbalancers = \ == 'pending_create': self.assertNotIn(loadbalancer, discovered_loadbalancers) else: self.assertIn(loadbalancer, discovered_loadbalancers) class TestLBStatsPollster(_BaseTestLBPollster): def setUp(self): super(TestLBStatsPollster, self).setUp() fake_balancer_stats = self.fake_balancer_stats() self.useFixture(mockpatch.Patch('ceilometer.neutron_client.Client.' 'get_loadbalancer_stats', return_value=fake_balancer_stats)) fake_loadbalancers = self.fake_list_loadbalancers() self.useFixture(mockpatch.Patch('ceilometer.neutron_client.Client.' 'list_loadbalancer', return_value=fake_loadbalancers)) cfg.CONF.set_override('neutron_lbaas_version', 'v2', group='service_types') @staticmethod def fake_list_loadbalancers(): return [{'operating_status': 'ONLINE', 'description': '', 'admin_state_up': True, 'tenant_id': '1a3e005cf9ce40308c900bcb08e5320c', 'provisioning_status': 'ACTIVE', 'listeners': [{'id': 'fe7rad36-437d-4c84-aee1-186027d3bdcd'}], 'vip_address': '10.0.0.2', 'vip_subnet_id': '013d3059-87a4-45a5-91e9-d721068ae0b2', 'id': 'cd6a6fee-e2fa-4e6c-b3c2-bfbe395752c1', 'name': 'loadbalancer_online'}, ] @staticmethod def fake_balancer_stats(): return {'active_connections': 2, 'bytes_in': 1, 'bytes_out': 3, 'total_connections': 4} @mock.patch('ceilometer.pipeline.setup_pipeline', mock.MagicMock()) def _check_get_samples(self, factory, sample_name, expected_volume, expected_type): pollster = factory() cache = {} samples = list(pollster.get_samples(self.manager, cache, self.fake_list_loadbalancers())) self.assertEqual(1, len(samples)) self.assertIsNotNone(samples) self.assertIn('lbstats', cache) self.assertEqual(set([sample_name]), set([s.name for s in samples])) match = [s for s in samples if s.name == sample_name] self.assertEqual(1, len(match), 'missing counter %s' % sample_name) self.assertEqual(expected_volume, match[0].volume) self.assertEqual(expected_type, match[0].type) def test_lb_total_connections(self): self._check_get_samples(lbaas.LBTotalConnectionsPollster, 'network.services.lb.total.connections', 4, 'cumulative') def test_lb_active_connections(self): self._check_get_samples(lbaas.LBActiveConnectionsPollster, 'network.services.lb.active.connections', 2, 'gauge') def test_lb_incoming_bytes(self): self._check_get_samples(lbaas.LBBytesInPollster, 'network.services.lb.incoming.bytes', 1, 'gauge') def test_lb_outgoing_bytes(self): self._check_get_samples(lbaas.LBBytesOutPollster, 'network.services.lb.outgoing.bytes', 3, 'gauge')

Version 3.7.0 includes a generator hook for oslo_config, which
permits downstream projects to override upstream values during

commit_message:
Updated oslo.config to 3.7.0

Version 3.7.0 includes a generator hook for oslo_config, which
permits downstream projects to override upstream values during
config generation. It is required by CORS middleware, as including
these values in paste.ini was deemed a release blocker.

Change-Id: I1b2fcc1a46c24b2dd73f8194a6fdd990b77d9f36

commit_message:
Not use deprecated library function os.popen()

os.popen() is deprecated since python 2.6.
Resolved with use of subprocess module.

Change-Id: I044ea4f3c88b5701e675d6bd3f661ef7ac58512d
Closes-Bug: #1529836

remove redundant "#!/usr/bin/env python" header

There are some general python code files which have the
"#!/usr/bin/env python" header. This patch removes it.

subject: Update the CONF import path for VNC
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-08 13:44:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dfc6429d9c05b399224facb67ff7720c3c234893', 'message': "Update the CONF import path for VNC

The VNC conf options were recently moved to nova.conf.vnc as part of the
centralize-config-options blueprint.  This changes the import path for
the oslo import_opt command.

Most of the code just work because nova pre-imported the nova.conf
package.  But we found in the out-of-tree powervm driver that the
import_opt command needed to be changed from nova.vnc to nova.conf.vnc
to handle the new change.

This change set simply extends the changes into the core nova project.
While it doesn't seem to be causing a functional problem, it does bring
the nvoa code in line with what the oslo_config api expects.

With this change, if a file happens to be imported before the nova.conf
package is, oslo_config will be able to resolve the config option properly.

Change-Id: I36d767be527e655a89b7635f92433003a888ccbc
Implements: bp centralize-config-options
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-09 21:29:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d43920d4ed09a728df3abd157004a79a5c97c215', 'message': 'Update the CONF import path for VNC

The VNC conf options were recently moved to nova.conf.vnc as part of the
centralize-config-options blueprint.  This changes the import path for
the oslo import_opt command.

Most of the code just work because nova pre-imported the nova.conf
package.  But we found in the out-of-tree powervm driver that the
import_opt command needed to change the group to nova.conf.vnc to work.

The appropriate fix is instead of importing cfg.CONF, to have the code
import nova.conf.CONF.  This properly resolves all of the imports.

Change-Id: I36d767be527e655a89b7635f92433003a888ccbc
Implements: bp centralize-config-options
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-10 18:00:35.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/vmwareapi/vmops.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py', 'nova/virt/xenapi/vmops.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/98447ceb26f300dfacc2540ae621594b89ef6468', 'message': 'Update the CONF import path for VNC

centralize-config-options blueprint.  This changes the import path for
the oslo import_opt command.

Most of the code just work because nova pre-imported the nova.conf

commit_message:
Update the CONF import path for VNC

The VNC conf options were recently moved to nova.conf.vnc as part of the
centralize-config-options blueprint.  This changes the import path for
the oslo import_opt command.

Most of the code just work because nova pre-imported the nova.conf
package.  But we found in the out-of-tree powervm driver that the
import_opt command needed to change the group to nova.conf.vnc to work.

The appropriate fix is instead of importing cfg.CONF, to have the code
import nova.conf.CONF.  This properly resolves all of the imports.

Change-Id: I36d767be527e655a89b7635f92433003a888ccbc
Implements: bp centralize-config-options
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/277392/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.import_opt('enabled', 'nova.conf.vnc', group='vnc')

commit_message:
bug and tests in 'instance_info_cache'

Added unit tests for 'instance_info_cache' db section,
fixed incorrect behaviour with ignoring exception that relates
to introducing oslo.db enginefacade.

Closes-Bug: #1520563
Closes-Bug: #1520567

Co-Authored-By: Sergey Nikitin <snikitin@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Making health verification periodics distributed

* periodic tasks with health verifications now can be
  distributed across engines
* periodic tasks with health verifications will not be
  launched if verifications are disabled

Partially-implements bp: cluster-verification
Partially-implements bp: distributed-periodics

Change-Id: I6e9f1e53582a625ab157cf795a249d86e5667989

commit_message:
Docs: Explanation of dynamic inventory

This patch provides a common place to document the behavior of the
dynamic inventory scripts provided in tree. It is intentionally
high level, so as to be less influenced by minor changes to the
scripts.

The documentation lives in the developer docs for now, but is also
linked from the install guide as it's relevant to deployers as well.

NOTE: This cannot be backported directly to liberty, since the parameter
to dynamic_inventory.py for the configuration directory is different
(--file in liberty, --config in master)

Change-Id: Ib7e8603dd70cff1d6a29730619c023aadce7b5e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/57/284457/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: `Home <index.html>`_ OpenStack-Ansible Developer Documentation OpenStack-Ansible Inventory =========================== OpenStack-Ansible uses an included script to generate the inventory of hosts and containers within the environment. This script is called by Ansible through its `dynamic inventory functionality`_. This script lives in ``playbooks/inventory/dynamic_inventory.py``. Execution --------- When running an Ansible command (such as ``ansible``, ``ansible-playbook`` or ``openstack-ansible``) Ansible will execute the ``dynamic_inventory.py`` script and use its output as inventory. You can also manually run the script as follows: .. code-block:: bash # from the playbooks directory inventory/dynamic_inventory.py --file /etc/openstack_deploy/ This invocation is useful when testing changes to the dynamic inventory script. Inputs ------ The ``dynamic_inventory.py`` script takes a single argument, ``--file``. If not specified, the default is ``/etc/openstack_deploy/``. Within the specified directory, the following files must be present: * ``openstack_environment.yml`` * ``openstack_user_config.yml`` Additionally, the configuration or environment could be spread between two additional directories: * ``conf.d`` * ``env.d`` These files are used to build a definiton of the environment consumable by Ansible. Outputs ------- Once executed, the script will output an ``openstack_inventory.json`` file into the directory sepcified with the ``--file`` argument. This is used as a cache for repeated runs. The same JSON structure is printed to stdout, which is consumed by Ansible as the inventory for the playbooks. .. include:: navigation.txt .. _`dynamic inventory functionality`: http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/intro_dynamic_inventory.html

subject: Add Kilo to Liberty upgrade scaffold
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-23 21:56:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/7d9a7e9e2a0d20989cddd2acbdb47ec549606a5d', 'message': "Add Kilo to Liberty upgrade scaffold

This commit provides scaffolding for future Kilo to Liberty work. While
incomplete, this commit should provide a space for the upgrade work to

commit_message:
Add Kilo to Liberty upgrade scaffold

This commit provides scaffolding for future Kilo to Liberty work. While
incomplete, this commit should provide a space for the upgrade work to
be built open.

The `run_lock` function and its `RUN_TASKS` array are included as
the upgrade steps will be run through these methods, similar to the Juno
to Kilo process.

An upgrade guide section was added to the documentation so that further
work can be done there.

Since this commit is providing only a scaffold for the 'real' work to
follow, no release note has been added.

The work that needs to be done (in order of execution) is as follows:

    * Backup then update the environment/config files with Liberty
      values
    * Adjust the user secrets file for new secrets values.
    * Setup openstack and LXC hosts
    * Update container configurations
    * Restart container networking
    * Install/Upgrade infrastructure software (Galera, RabbitMQ)
    * Install Openstack Liberty code
    * Clean out RabbitMQ default vhost

Change-Id: Id1bb54039ca2fb15cbd3d199f777dbea063c9eec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/23/283823/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Add kombu_reconnect_delay option

commit_message:
Add kombu_reconnect_delay option

The kombu_reconnect_delay is used when configuring rabbitmq but we are
missing the parameter from the base trove class. This change adds it in
and adds test coverage for the rabbit user, password, host, ssl and
reconnect delay.

Change-Id: I8a5e7f0241a0f41e4f10b40d791f39e37ce82087
Closes-Bug: #1545168

commit_message:
Add ability to manually install puppet modules

This commit adds the ability to manually install puppet modules. This is
useful when using an installation method not provided by the
PUPPETFILE_DIR environment variable.

Change-Id: Ie6519d8adb989eaec59d2f3047205c4fa2212419
(cherry picked from commit bc818cbc65fc47061b918e020572d92c296b6111)

commit_message:
Use 'publish-to-pypi' job for 'fuel-plugins' repo

Best practices say: "Do not use bare hands, automate it!". In order to
reduce manual tasks and simplify workflow, it would be really nice if
CI uploads new releases to PyPI on our behalf.

Change-Id: Ie1bbcf2cedc254c185b1182a13f24a67af660a1c

commit_message:
Update translation setup

Follow new infra setup for translations, see spec
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack-infra/infra-specs/specs/translation_setup.html
for full details.

The default path of POT file is changed to
$modulename/locale/$modulename.pot and
translation domain is changed from $reponame to $modulename.

Change-Id: Ia032c54bf8218cac232e5dd730875c3e3e18c01c

commit_message:
Explicitly add openvswitch_agent.ini to OVS agent commandline

Commit Ic170d932df53bb1d7bd3b0eda116ad36d0b929c6 moved some required options
for OVS agent to /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/openvswitch_agent.ini which is not
loaded by MOS packages. Explicitly add to OVS agent commandline until MOS
packages will be updated

Change-Id: I901c7209f9d2c9e68698683c51bce4764db79031
Closes-bug: #1549934

commit_message:
Make Manila single-backend job nonvoting

The gate-manila-tempest-dsvm-neutron job overlaps with and
has less test coverage than
gate-manila-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multibackend. Since both have
a chance to fail randomly due to unfixed bug outside our control,
make gate-manila-tempest-dsvm-neutron non-voting for now.

Change-Id: I3e7406cc94463fbb5118fb90230ff7d94621797f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/90/284790/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
PuppetOpenStack CI: save OpenStack Infra resources

Only run the scenarios we need to test for each Puppet module and stop
running all scenarios for all modules (waste of resources).

It will:
* save resources in OpenStack infra
* reduce time of CI
* reduce risk of failure

Depends-On: I39870bbac6f2f9a050f85772d1fb0f6ac839e410

commit_message:
Check Status Code in Monasca Client

Raise an exception if the status code from monasca api is not 200

Change-Id: I5f7b63c885b0794caa23426217c54cdd4be8b578
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-monascaclient refs/changes/19/278819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2014-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP resp = self._make_request(method, url, allow_redirects, timeout, **kwargs) if self._unauthorized(resp): # re-authenticate and attempt one more request try: self.re_authenticate() kwargs['headers']['X-Auth-Token'] = self.auth_token resp = self._make_request(method, url, allow_redirects, timeout, **kwargs) self._check_status_code(resp, method, **kwargs) except Exception as e: raise exc.HTTPUnauthorized(e) else: self._check_status_code(resp, method, **kwargs) return resp def _unauthorized(self, resp): status401 = (resp.status_code == 401) status500 = (resp.status_code == 500 and "(HTTP 401)" in resp.content) return status401 or status500 def _check_status_code(self, resp, method, **kwargs): if self._unauthorized(resp): message = "Unauthorized error" raise exc.HTTPUnauthorized(message) elif 400 <= resp.status_code < 600: raise exc.from_response(resp) elif resp.status_code in (301, 302, 305): # Redirected. Reissue the request to the new location. location = resp.headers.get('location') if location is None: message = "Location not returned with 302" raise exc.InvalidEndpoint(message=message) elif location.startswith(self.endpoint): # shave off the endpoint, it will be prepended when we recurse location = location[len(self.endpoint):] else: message = "Prohibited endpoint redirect %s" % location raise exc.InvalidEndpoint(message=message) return self._http_request(location, method, **kwargs) elif resp.status_code == 300: raise exc.from_response(resp) def _make_request(self, method, url, allow_redirects, timeout, **kwargs):
deleted_lines: # (C) Copyright 2014-2015 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP if (resp.status_code == 401 or (resp.status_code == 500 and "(HTTP 401)" in resp.content)): # re-authenticate and attempt one more request try: self.re_authenticate() kwargs['headers']['X-Auth-Token'] = self.auth_token resp = requests.request( method, self.endpoint_url + url, allow_redirects=allow_redirects, timeout=timeout, **kwargs) except Exception as e: raise exc.HTTPUnauthorized(e) elif 400 <= resp.status_code < 600: raise exc.from_response(resp) elif resp.status_code in (301, 302, 305): # Redirected. Reissue the request to the new location. location = resp.headers.get('location') if location is None: message = "Location not returned with 302" raise exc.InvalidEndpoint(message=message) elif location.startswith(self.endpoint): # shave off the endpoint, it will be prepended when we recurse location = location[len(self.endpoint):] else: message = "Prohibited endpoint redirect %s" % location raise exc.InvalidEndpoint(message=message) return self._http_request(location, method, **kwargs) elif resp.status_code == 300: raise exc.from_response(resp)

commit_message:
HAProxy and Keepalived upgrade

This is single task to upgrade both haproxy and keepalived. It stops
slave nodes of keepalived and upgrades them separately to avoid
VIP migration and allow nearly no-downtime upgrade

Change-Id: I06124635a3f3553a4e8e91013cefbf897dd7179f
Implements: blueprint upgrade-haproxy
Implements: blueprint upgrade-keepalived
Partially-implements: blueprint upgrade-kolla

subject: Catch NoPoolFound on resource listing in transport
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 17:35:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/674735d8948311a39650b856da244d480d447db4', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolsFound on queue list on websocket API

"queue_list" operation should catch any storage errors to return 503
error response, but the line "queues = list(next(results))", which can
throw NoPoolFound exception, is outside try block.

This patch moves the line inside try block, so exception will be
properly handled.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-23 12:47:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/b099bae1d87400ef8a9d34b00bba5849d2481382', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolFound on queue list on websocket API

"queue_list" operation should catch any storage errors to return 503
error response, but the line "queues = list(next(results))", which can
throw NoPoolFound exception, is outside try block.

This patch moves the line inside try block, so exception will be
properly handled.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-23 17:25:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/d40790c021def08f6a31e4b747a3183e5bcf63af', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolFound on queue list on websocket API

"queue_list" operation should catch any storage errors to return 503
error response, but the line "queues = list(next(results))", which can
throw NoPoolFound exception, is outside try block.

This patch moves the line inside try block, so exception will be
properly handled. This patch also adds test for this specific case.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-02-23 18:01:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/8753bf0fdf67f76f736e0920c83b7990be34a7d5', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolFound on queue list on websocket API

"queue_list" operation should catch any storage errors to return 503
error response, but the line "queues = list(next(results))", which can
throw NoPoolFound exception, is outside try block.

This patch moves the line inside try block, so exception will be
properly handled. This patch also adds test for this specific case.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-02-23 21:16:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/538705130cb9dafb3c182bf23fcd40262fea0be5', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolFound on resource listing in transport

For example, "queue_list" operation in Websocket transport should catch
any storage errors to return 503 error response, but the line
"queues = list(next(results))", which can throw NoPoolFound exception,
is outside try block.

This problem not only affects "queue_list" operation in Websocket
transport, but also some other places.

This patch moves such lines inside try blocks, so exception will be
properly handled. This patch also adds tests for this specific case.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-02-23 22:54:55.000000000', 'files': ['zaqar/tests/unit/transport/wsgi/v2_0/test_queue_lifecycle.py', 'zaqar/api/v2/endpoints.py', 'zaqar/transport/wsgi/v2_0/subscriptions.py', 'zaqar/tests/unit/transport/websocket/v2/test_subscriptions.py', 'zaqar/tests/unit/transport/wsgi/v1/test_queue_lifecycle.py', 'zaqar/tests/unit/transport/wsgi/v2_0/test_subscriptions.py', 'zaqar/tests/unit/transport/websocket/v2/test_queue_lifecycle.py', 'zaqar/tests/unit/transport/wsgi/v1_1/test_queue_lifecycle.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/e58bdc4bb72742f775c27a4b66090fea828a3837', 'message': 'Catch NoPoolFound on resource listing in transport

any storage errors to return 503 error response, but the line
"queues = list(next(results))", which can throw NoPoolFound exception,
is outside try block.

This problem not only affects "queue_list" operation in Websocket
transport, but also some other places.

This patch moves such lines inside try blocks, so exception will be
properly handled. This patch also adds tests for this specific case.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795
'}]
commit_message:
Catch NoPoolFound on resource listing in transport

For example, "queue_list" operation in Websocket transport should catch
any storage errors to return 503 error response, but the line
"queues = list(next(results))", which can throw NoPoolFound exception,
is outside try block.

This problem not only affects "queue_list" operation in Websocket
transport, but also some other places.

This patch moves such lines inside try blocks, so exception will be
properly handled. This patch also adds tests for this specific case.

Change-Id: I5557aee5c0e4c1127f54b2059164bd1a0627c89d
Closes-Bug: 1538795

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-log-api refs/changes/55/283055/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Healthcheck Log-Api comes with builtin health check mechanism. It is available in two flavours both accessible under ```/healthcheck``` endpoint. ## Fat check Fat check not only response with success code if Log-Api is up and running. Additionally it verifies peripheral component - **Kafka**. API will respond with following codes: * 200 - both API and Kafka are running. Requested topics are available in broker. * 503 - API is running but problems with Kafka has been spotted. It means that either Kafka is down or requested topics are not available. Example: ```curl -XGET 192.168.10.4:8080/healthcheck``` ## Lean check Lean check only tells you that API is up and running. It does not return any data because it is accessible only for ```HEAD``` requests. If API is up and running following response code: ```204``` is expected. Example: ```curl -XHEAD 192.168.10.4:8080/healthcheck```

commit_message:
Fix exception thrown when dimensions missing

The batching feature now requires dimensions to be
present at entity level or it throws
HTTPUnprocessableEntityError. There is no such
exception and I believe the author meant to say
HTTPUnprocessableEntity. This commit fixes that.

Change-Id: Iceb16f06e30f01ed7c776444a9fe4baf8428c173

commit_message:
loadbalancer: fix MySQL timeout HAproxy config

Current HAproxy config is broken for MySQL timeout parameters.
This is what we have today by default in HAproxy logs:
--------------
[WARNING] 238/115010 (13878) : config : missing timeouts for proxy
'mysql'.
| While not properly invalid, you will certainly encounter various
problems
| with such a configuration. To fix this, please ensure that all
following
| timeouts are set to a non-zero value: 'client', 'connect', 'server'.
--------------

This patch aims to:
* Use the correct parameters to configure puppetlabs-haproxy
* Update the database timeouts to higher values to prevent the
services from disconnecting too frequently by setting the Galera HAProxy
timeout to 90 minutes.

Change-Id: I06dd4bf81d4f4fd3c01bb681f6f0b3152f2b8eea
(cherry picked from commit 00ca7b29602b2e49fe537777db06f9f1a03028f2)

commit_message:
Make online_data_migrations do smaller batches in unlimited case

We want to have a single command that people can run to do all of their
online migrations in a single go. This is the closest thing to the
old model of "run all my database migrations, let me know when it's
done." The code right now ends up doing a single batch of unlimited size,
which will undoubtedly run out of memory for large enough deployments.

This patch makes us execute smaller batches until we're done. If
people want to optimize this, they can control the batch size and
do their own looping, but we need a reasonable option for people
that just want one-shot without the potential for the OOM.

Change-Id: I07ec2aeb0c305dd1a088ca590f3c91a8ced10787

commit_message:
Remove support for trust scoped tokens in v2.0

Previous commits removed support for validating trust scoped tokens
against the v2.0 API. This commit finishes that patch by removing
support for obtaining a trust scoped token against the v2.0 API.

Change-Id: Icc9a122039f8ee979836678925f1553622879096

General improvements to quickstart

- Provided info on installing ansible via yum from EPEL and pointed
  readers to the EPEL docs to learn how to install/enable the repo

Change-Id: I4bf87fbf90779be85293eb65fe7cd2ffe548d6ae

added_lines: Docker versions greater than 1.10.0 are functional with master branch (Mitaka), while Docker 1.8.3 and later are incompatible with Kolla Liberty. commit_message:
Remove limitation on networking-ovn git location

Current Vagrantfile creates symbolic link to ~/networking-ovn.  This
forces the git clone to be done into the users $HOME directory. Update
Vagrantfile and README.rst to remove this restriction.

Change-Id: I89da3dc83a1be3248459e36d98fc063757c757a6
Signed-off-by: John Kasperski <jckasper@us.ibm.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-23 00:53:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/dd40d2865998190568ce8dcd49748748ea88dc8a', 'message': 'Backport: Store openstack_host_sysstat_enabled as lower case

Closes-Bug: #1530979
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-23 10:31:08.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/roles/openstack_hosts/defaults/main.yml', 'playbooks/roles/openstack_hosts/templates/sysstat.default.j2', 'playbooks/roles/openstack_hosts/templates/sysstat.cron.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/6193998108a98bfb8e1655749b9aea142a5eb520', 'message': 'Store openstack_host_sysstat_enabled as lower case value for sysstat.default.j2

Sysstat won't enable unless the ENABLED switch has been set to true.
Passing openstack_host_sysstat_enabled as true inside jinja will end
up as a "True" value inside the /etc/default/sysstat rather then the
expected "true" value and sysstat won't start.

The added jinja filter lower will make sure that the boolean is always
stored in lower case.

Additionally 'openstack_host_systat_enabled' was renamed to
'openstack_host_sysstat_enabled' to better reflect the dependency to
sysstat.

This is a backport of https://review.openstack.org/263427

Change-Id: I4c8ac77c29ae4f3a1f6331fdaaab5d45abadcf44
Closes-Bug: #1530979'}]
commit_message:
Store openstack_host_sysstat_enabled as lower case value for sysstat.default.j2

Sysstat won't enable unless the ENABLED switch has been set to true.
Passing openstack_host_sysstat_enabled as true inside jinja will end
up as a "True" value inside the /etc/default/sysstat rather then the
expected "true" value and sysstat won't start.

The added jinja filter lower will make sure that the boolean is always
stored in lower case.

Additionally 'openstack_host_systat_enabled' was renamed to
'openstack_host_sysstat_enabled' to better reflect the dependency to
sysstat.

This is a backport of https://review.openstack.org/263427

Change-Id: I4c8ac77c29ae4f3a1f6331fdaaab5d45abadcf44
Closes-Bug: #1530979

subject: Add allow-local-ssh-root to the packstack integration jobs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-23 22:21:02.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/packstack.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/7301e565ae567aad8f4aa72cab2164c7750d5f51', 'message': 'Add allow-local-ssh-root to the packstack integration jobs

Packstack actually logs in to the nodes it wants to configure, even
if that node is localhost and an "all-in-one".

Change-Id: Ibcfa11efd99692872c6ae439779f8e5dbc9bf03b
'}]
commit_message:
Add allow-local-ssh-root to the packstack integration jobs

Packstack actually logs in to the nodes it wants to configure, even
if that node is localhost and an "all-in-one".

We could handle that logic from inside the job but since there is
a builder that does just that, let's leverage it.

Change-Id: Ibcfa11efd99692872c6ae439779f8e5dbc9bf03b

commit_message:
Add the neutron-pg job back into the check queue, non-voting

Possibly the previous race conditions that kicked this job out of the
gate have been addressed as part of the pymysql fixes. Let's start
getting some data, and see if we can find some bugs.

Change-Id: Id40fe990e61a09ebb9e99528f37402c19ccef3c2

commit_message:
Add transaction context for stack update

stack update does not use a demarcated transaction
hence does not flush object changes to the database
which can result in StaleDataError when session.flush()
is called later.

Change-Id: I00afd543dabd33f4d6d18e900cc4aefbd2643076
Closes-Bug: #1536488

commit_message:
Run allow-local-ssh-root after gerrit-git-prep

gerrit-git-prep inconveniently deletes the .ssh directory with
the ssh keypair allow-local-ssh-root creates. Let's run it after
so it doesn't delete it.

Change-Id: I4bb265ab8a0b648848f2005fa8ff7220e7b70ae4

commit_message:
Properly preallocate qcow images.

Qcow images were not properly preallocated. The 'fallocate' function
was being called with the size of the image, not including the qcow2
metadata.

Metadata preallocation of qcow images should improve performance
as well as properly preallocate the space required for the disk.

Closes-Bug: #1510328
Change-Id: I52a089caba6199d42f949fc444582c1525752b6d

Just need to # fallocate on the reported size of the image. size = os.path.getsize(path) super(Qcow2, self)._preallocate(path, size)

commit_message:
Trivial: remove `None` as a redundant argument to dict.get()

`dict.get()` returns `None` by default, if a key wasn't found.
Removing `None` as second argument to avoid redundancy.

Change-Id: I898219110206e9c49348f9a36f07b5ba1766f0f1

commit_message:
Don't print HTTP codes for non-HTTP errors

This changes:
 $ cinder rename asdf
 ERROR: Must supply either name or description. (HTTP 1)

To:
 $ cinder rename asdf
 ERROR: Must supply either name or description.

Affects rename, snapshot-rename, consisgroup-update,
and consisgroup-create-from-src.
(consisgroup-* previously printed HTTP 400.)

Closes-Bug: #1549020
Closes-Bug: #1549026
Change-Id: Ia920b3b75b53170789b694cbdd49100bd6a72d21

commit_message:
Fix the typo in the gnocchiclient exception

NamedMetricAreadyExists has been renamed to the NamedMetricAlreadyExists
in the last release of Gnocchi client

commit_message:
Consolidate the fernet provider validate_v2_token()

When the Fernet token provider was implemented, it extended the
provider.common.py:BaseProvider class. It also overrode most all common methods
the BaseProvider implemented. Other token providers in Keystone (like the UUID
an PKI providers) just implemente a _get_token_id method because token ids may
be different across providers.

This commit removes the validate_v2_token() method from the fernet.Provider.
This ensure that the Fernet provider uses the same validate_v2_token() that all
the other token providers use.

Change-Id: I1373a8352a92e720ef7df8b926bfb95bcb5963a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/06/197706/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # FIXME(lbragstad): Consolidate this into BaseProvider.validate_v2_token() def validate_v2_token(self, token_ref): """Validate a V2 formatted token. :param token_ref: reference describing the token to validate :returns: the token data :raises keystone.exception.Unauthorized: if v3 token is used """ (user_id, methods, audit_ids, domain_id, project_id, trust_id, federated_info, created_at, expires_at) = self.token_formatter.validate_token(token_ref) if trust_id or domain_id or federated_info: msg = _('This is not a v2.0 Fernet token. Use v3 for trust, ' 'domain, or federated tokens.') raise exception.Unauthorized(msg) v3_token_data = self.v3_token_data_helper.get_token_data( user_id, methods, project_id=project_id, expires=expires_at, issued_at=created_at, token=token_ref, include_catalog=False, audit_info=audit_ids) return self.v2_token_data_helper.v3_to_v2_token(token_ref, v3_token_data)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary translate attribute for docker_volume_size

In BayModel detail view, docker_volume_size uses Horizon's
filter. The filter uses gettext within it.

So we should remove translate attribute for docker_volume_size.
Otherwise Zanata shows the message as to be translated.

This patch remove translate attribute for docker_volume_size
in BayModel detail view.

Change-Id: I0e3a96204c2d9238a97c0cb6c2d01396cbe58f0f
Closes-Bug: #1548572

commit_message:
Add support for root enable and show

Added an entry in the instance details panel to show whether root has
ever been enabled for the instance.

Added a manage root access screen to allow the user to enable the root
user or reset the root password.

The manage root access screen is accessed from a row menu option in the
database instances table.

Change-Id: I781f55f6184e0b83fe56fce6143269aa48b1c46d
Co-Authored-By: Duk Loi <duk@tesora.com>
Implements: blueprint trove-enable-root-support

added_lines: class EnableRootInfo(object): def __init__(self, instance_id, instance_name, enabled, password=None): self.id = instance_id self.name = instance_name self.enabled = enabled self.password = password class ManageRootView(horizon_tables.DataTableView): table_class = tables.ManageRootTable template_name = 'project/databases/manage_root.html' page_title = _("Manage Root Access") @memoized.memoized_method def get_data(self): instance_id = self.kwargs['instance_id'] try: instance = api.trove.instance_get(self.request, instance_id) except Exception: redirect = reverse('horizon:project:databases:detail', args=[instance_id]) exceptions.handle(self.request, _('Unable to retrieve instance details.'), redirect=redirect) try: enabled = api.trove.root_show(self.request, instance_id) except Exception: redirect = reverse('horizon:project:databases:detail', args=[instance_id]) exceptions.handle(self.request, _('Unable to determine if instance root ' 'is enabled.'), redirect=redirect) root_enabled_list = [] root_enabled_info = EnableRootInfo(instance.id, instance.name, enabled.rootEnabled) root_enabled_list.append(root_enabled_info) return root_enabled_list def get_context_data(self, **kwargs): context = super(ManageRootView, self).get_context_data(**kwargs) context['instance_id'] = self.kwargs['instance_id'] return context

subject: Make Rally cope with unversioned keystone URL
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 01:23:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/a591bf50db7764d51bc083efa1e1b88925d57c46', 'message': "Make Rally cope with unversioned keystone URL

This is the second attempt to get this code merged after the previous
version was reverted apparently due to these bugs:
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1545889
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1547092
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1544839

The only genuine bug was the first one - defining endpoints in your
deployment config broke things. The other two are not the fault of this
change as explained in the bugs' comments.

The new changes are to force a pre-auth using a different mechanism to
the previous approach that was calling the deprecated
client.authenticate() method. Instead, it's now calling
auth.get_access(session) which returns an auth_ref that we can store on
the client.

Note that this is all only needed because Rally needs the service_type,
which is only returned in the service_catalog and not the API's
enpoints.list().

Previous commit message below:
---
The way in which OSClient was constructing a keystone client was flawed
and using a deprecated method. It was also second guessing the
discovery process, which keystoneclient itself can handle on its own.

The main symptom of the flawed approach was that you were unable to use
keystone URLs in the catalog that didn't have the version appended,
e.g.:
  * http://foo.rally:5000/v3
  versus
  * http://foo.rally:5000/

The latter form is the correct form according to the Keystone
developers I spoke to.

With the change, the client version that's returned is now determined by
the keystoneclient library itself based on whether you supply a URL
with a version in it or not.

Change-Id: I31daf8c0bdb7d9329f14722fcd0f51cc23519158
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-25 01:26:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/648c55c68f6b87bf24f49b84eb811daa523f30e6', 'message': "Make Rally cope with unversioned keystone URL

This is the second attempt to get this code merged after the previous
version was reverted apparently due to these bugs:
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1545889
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1547092
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1544839

The only genuine bug was the first one - defining endpoints in your
deployment config broke things. The other two are not the fault of this
change as explained in the bugs' comments.

The new changes are to force a pre-auth using a different mechanism to
the previous approach that was calling the deprecated
client.authenticate() method. Instead, it's now calling
auth.get_access(session) which returns an auth_ref that we can store on
the client.

Note that this is all only needed because Rally needs the service_type,
which is only returned in the service_catalog and not the API's
enpoints.list().

Previous commit message below:
---
The way in which OSClient was constructing a keystone client was flawed
and using a deprecated method. It was also second guessing the
discovery process, which keystoneclient itself can handle on its own.

The main symptom of the flawed approach was that you were unable to use
keystone URLs in the catalog that didn't have the version appended,
e.g.:
  * http://foo.rally:5000/v3
  versus
  * http://foo.rally:5000/

The latter form is the correct form according to the Keystone
developers I spoke to.

With the change, the client version that's returned is now determined by
the keystoneclient library itself based on whether you supply a URL
with a version in it or not.

Fixes: 1547143
Fixes: 1545889

Change-Id: I31daf8c0bdb7d9329f14722fcd0f51cc23519158

commit_message:
Make Rally cope with unversioned keystone URL

This is the second attempt to get this code merged after the previous
version was reverted apparently due to these bugs:
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1545889
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1547092
 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/rally/+bug/1544839

The only genuine bug was the first one - defining endpoints in your
deployment config broke things. The other two are not the fault of this
change as explained in the bugs' comments.

The new changes are to force a pre-auth using a different mechanism to
the previous approach that was calling the deprecated
client.authenticate() method. Instead, it's now calling
auth.get_access(session) which returns an auth_ref that we can store on
the client.

Note that this is all only needed because Rally needs the service_type,
which is only returned in the service_catalog and not the API's
enpoints.list().

Previous commit message below:
---
The way in which OSClient was constructing a keystone client was flawed
and using a deprecated method. It was also second guessing the
discovery process, which keystoneclient itself can handle on its own.

The main symptom of the flawed approach was that you were unable to use
keystone URLs in the catalog that didn't have the version appended,
e.g.:
  * http://foo.rally:5000/v3
  versus
  * http://foo.rally:5000/

The latter form is the correct form according to the Keystone
developers I spoke to.

With the change, the client version that's returned is now determined by
the keystoneclient library itself based on whether you supply a URL
with a version in it or not.

Closes-Bug: 1547143
Closes-Bug: 1545889

Change-Id: I31daf8c0bdb7d9329f14722fcd0f51cc23519158
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/18/282918/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if auth is None: endpoint = endpoint or self._get_endpoint() kc = self.keystone() def _create_keystone_client(self, args): from keystoneclient.auth import identity from keystoneclient import client auth_arg_list = [ "username", "project_name", "tenant_name", "auth_url", "password", ] # NOTE(bigjools): If forcing a v2.0 URL then you cannot specify # domain-related info, or the service discovery will fail. if "v2.0" not in args["auth_url"]: auth_arg_list.extend( ["user_domain_name", "domain_name", "project_domain_name"]) auth_args = {key: args.get(key) for key in auth_arg_list} auth = identity.Password(**auth_args) session = self._get_session(auth=auth) args["session"] = session # NOTE(bigjools): When using sessions, keystoneclient no longer # does any pre-auth and calling client.authenticate() with # sessions is deprecated (it's still possible to call it but if # endpoint is defined it'll crash). We're forcing that pre-auth # here because the use of the service_catalog depends on doing # this. Also note that while the API has got the # endpoints.list() equivalent, there is no service_type in that # list which is why we need to ensure service_catalog is still # present. auth_ref = auth.get_access(session) ks = client.Client(**args) ks.auth_ref = auth_ref return ks return self._create_keystone_client(kw)
deleted_lines: endpoint = endpoint or self._get_endpoint() kc = self.keystone() if auth is None: @staticmethod def _create_keystone_client(args): from keystoneclient import discover as keystone_discover discover = keystone_discover.Discover(**args) for version_data in discover.version_data(): version = version_data["version"] if version[0] <= 2: from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as keystone_v2 return keystone_v2.Client(**args) elif version[0] == 3: from keystoneclient.v3 import client as keystone_v3 return keystone_v3.Client(**args) raise exceptions.RallyException("Failed to discover keystone version " "for url %(auth_url)s.", **args) client = self._create_keystone_client(kw) if client.auth_ref is None: client.authenticate() return client

commit_message:
Init oslo_context before magnum context init

Roles is added as a member of oslo.context since oslo 2.2.0
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271928/
This causes magnum gate fail because roles is overwrited by
oslo_context. Let's init oslo_context first and then make
our local changes.

Change-Id: Iac8c568bd49fbc66d2d65c9b6083bc9895a8069c
Closes-Bug: #1549694
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/04/284604/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: request_id=request_id, roles=roles)

commit_message:
Added user accounts information to ProvisioningSerializer90

OS user account settings now are being passed to Fuel agent
during image build stage via ProvisioningSerializer90

Blueprint: fuel-nonroot-openstack-nodes

Change-Id: Ia18305e07d07377886783c3b3e44abe93cef2da5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/85/258185/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def serialize_node(cls, cluster_attrs, node): serialized_node = super(ProvisioningSerializer80, cls).serialize_node( cluster_attrs, node) os_user_authkeys = cluster_attrs.get('os_user_authkeys', '').split('\n') os_user = { 'name': cluster_attrs.get('os_user_name', 'fueladmin'), 'password': cluster_attrs.get('os_user_password', 'fueladmin'), 'homedir': cluster_attrs.get('os_user_homedir', '/home/fueladmin'), 'sudo': cluster_attrs.get('os_user_sudo', '').split('\n'), } serialized_node['ks_meta']['os_user'] = os_user [serialized_node['ks_meta']['authorized_keys'].append("\"%s\"" % key) for key in os_user_authkeys] return serialized_node

commit_message:
Set 0644 file mode for volume content files

We need read rights for everyone to make regular user possible to
export system test environments without superuser privileges.
Also it helps to save time when older version of libvirt with poor
vol-download performance is used.

Change-Id: I1edc668f97c81a58a2ebaae8e3a03e2cd0d1a319

commit_message:
Add backend tests from glance

Moves some unit tests that were part of glance but should have
belonged to glance_store.

These tests are ported from
glance/tests/unit/test_store_image.py

Related-Bug: #1548902

NOTE(mriedem): As part of the backport we have to remove
the verifier=None kwargs from the assertions made in
test_backend since the verifier code didn't exist in
stable/liberty.

Change-Id: I688629d37e9146aef33fbc9bb6fd8780521e06ab
(cherry picked from commit 5faadde2d63d0bb7de12958c6e79040d6cc0448c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/89/283689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 OpenStack, LLC # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Tests the backend store API's""" import mock from glance_store import backend from glance_store import exceptions from glance_store.tests import base class TestStoreAddToBackend(base.StoreBaseTest): def setUp(self): super(TestStoreAddToBackend, self).setUp() self.image_id = "animage" self.data = "dataandstuff" self.size = len(self.data) self.location = "file:///ab/cde/fgh" self.checksum = "md5" def _bad_metadata(self, in_metadata): mstore = mock.Mock() mstore.add.return_value = (self.location, self.size, self.checksum, in_metadata) mstore.__str__ = lambda self: "hello" mstore.__unicode__ = lambda self: "hello" self.assertRaises(exceptions.BackendException, backend.store_add_to_backend, self.image_id, self.data, self.size, mstore) mstore.add.assert_called_once_with(self.image_id, mock.ANY, self.size, context=None, verifier=None) def _good_metadata(self, in_metadata): mstore = mock.Mock() mstore.add.return_value = (self.location, self.size, self.checksum, in_metadata) (location, size, checksum, metadata) = backend.store_add_to_backend(self.image_id, self.data, self.size, mstore) mstore.add.assert_called_once_with(self.image_id, mock.ANY, self.size, context=None, verifier=None) self.assertEqual(self.location, location) self.assertEqual(self.size, size) self.assertEqual(self.checksum, checksum) self.assertEqual(in_metadata, metadata) def test_empty(self): metadata = {} self._good_metadata(metadata) def test_string(self): metadata = {'key': u'somevalue'} self._good_metadata(metadata) def test_list(self): m = {'key': [u'somevalue', u'2']} self._good_metadata(m) def test_unicode_dict(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} m = {'topkey': inner} self._good_metadata(m) def test_unicode_dict_list(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} m = {'topkey': inner, 'list': [u'somevalue', u'2'], 'u': u'2'} self._good_metadata(m) def test_nested_dict(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} inner = {'newkey': inner} inner = {'anotherkey': inner} m = {'topkey': inner} self._good_metadata(m) def test_bad_top_level_nonunicode(self): metadata = {'key': b'a string'} self._bad_metadata(metadata) def test_bad_nonunicode_dict_list(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue', 'k3': [1, object()]} m = {'topkey': inner, 'list': [u'somevalue', u'2'], 'u': u'2'} self._bad_metadata(m) def test_bad_metadata_not_dict(self): self._bad_metadata([])

Add identity_uri parameter to ironic-api

they are replaced by auth_uri/identity_uri

commit_message:
Expand Nova API benchmark in Rally

Add support for listing nova hosts, agents, availability-zones
and aggregates.

blueprint extend-api-benchmark-in-nova-scenarios

Change-Id: I1facd17719299128e758334b468c01a83518889e

subject: Fix client not working on Python 3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-25 04:29:48.000000000', 'files': ['zaqarclient/transport/request.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient/commit/640f56a1dbe9682e600d1a2a4b430dca5559b51b', 'message': 'Fix client not working on Python 3

Currently the client is not working at all on Python 3 when it uses
Keystone authentication, and no project id is specified by user.

It is because in this case the client prepares a request with
'X-Project-Id' header assigned to {} (empty dictionary) value. The
Python 3 standard HTTP library expects all passed headers to be strings
and fails when one of the headers is dictionary:

  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/http/client.py", line 1069, in putheader
    value = b'\r\n\t'.join(values)
TypeError: sequence item 0: expected bytes, bytearray, or an object with
the buffer interface, dict found

This patch solves the problem by making the client not add
'X-Project-Id' to request at all in this case.

Change-Id: I7296b08d273b7173a9f6deb0ae9fb6ff929366db
Closes-Bug: 1525973
'}]
commit_message:
Fix client not working on Python 3

Currently the client is not working at all on Python 3 when it uses
Keystone authentication, and no project id is specified by user.

It is because in this case the client prepares a request with
'X-Project-Id' header assigned to {} (empty dictionary) value. The
Python 3 standard HTTP library expects all passed headers to be strings
and fails when one of the headers is dictionary:

  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/http/client.py", line 1069, in putheader
    value = b'\r\n\t'.join(values)
TypeError: sequence item 0: expected bytes, bytearray, or an object with
the buffer interface, dict found

This patch solves the problem by making the client not add
'X-Project-Id' to request at all in this case.

Change-Id: I7296b08d273b7173a9f6deb0ae9fb6ff929366db
Closes-Bug: 1525973
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/90/271890/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

As the disk number of iSCSI attached disks can change after host
reboot, passthrough attached volumes can get attached in this case.

This bug was partially fixed during Icehouse by this patch:

One of the issues with this patch is that it only handles SCSI
attached disks, for which reason this issue continues to occur when
having generation 1 VMs booted from volume, in which case the disk
will be placed on the IDE controller.

In this case, one instance may end up booting from another tenant's
volume, which is a critical security issue.

Also, it assumes that the block device info volume order matches
the according disk controller slot order, which is wrong.

This patch fixes this issue, looping through the block device
info and fixing the disk path for all the passthrough attached
disks, regardless of the disk controller.

This requires the virtual disk resources attached to the instance
to be tagged with the serial number.

Closes-Bug: #1526831

commit_message:
HyperV: Fix vm disk path issue

As the disk number of iSCSI attached disks can change after host
reboot, passthrough attached volumes can get attached in this case.

This bug was partially fixed during Icehouse by this patch:
https://review.openstack.org/95356

One of the issues with this patch is that it only handles SCSI
attached disks, for which reason this issue continues to occur when
having generation 1 VMs booted from volume, in which case the disk
will be placed on the IDE controller.

In this case, one instance may end up booting from another tenant's
volume, which is a critical security issue.

Also, it assumes that the block device info volume order matches
the according disk controller slot order, which is wrong.

This patch fixes this issue, looping through the block device
info and fixing the disk path for all the passthrough attached
disks, regardless of the disk controller.

This requires the virtual disk resources attached to the instance
to be tagged with the serial number.

Co-Authored-By: Alin Balutoiu <abalutoiu@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Closes-Bug: #1526831
Depends-On: Ibe463ce9ffb9129cab4b99fe7967ccb5f2181958
Change-Id: Icf8697d917c814ec120fce9898661eb9a20ade48
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/258615/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not mapping: return # Mapping containing virtual disk resource path and the physical # disk path for each volume serial number. The physical path # associated with this resource may not be the right one, # as physical disk paths can get swapped after host reboots. vm_disk_mapping = self._vmutils.get_vm_physical_disk_mapping( instance_name) # Mapping containing the current disk paths for each volume. actual_disk_mapping = self.get_disk_path_mapping(block_device_info) for serial, vm_disk in vm_disk_mapping.items(): actual_disk_path = actual_disk_mapping[serial] if vm_disk['mounted_disk_path'] != actual_disk_path: self._vmutils.set_disk_host_resource(vm_disk['resource_path'], actual_disk_path) def get_disk_path_mapping(self, block_device_info): block_mapping = driver.block_device_info_get_mapping(block_device_info) disk_path_mapping = {} for vol in block_mapping: connection_info = vol['connection_info'] disk_serial = connection_info['serial'] disk_path = self.get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume(connection_info) disk_path_mapping[disk_serial] = disk_path return disk_path_mapping def get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume(self, connection_info): volume_driver = self._get_volume_driver( connection_info=connection_info) return volume_driver.get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume( connection_info) def get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume(self, connection_info): data = connection_info['data'] target_lun = data['target_lun'] target_iqn = data['target_iqn'] # Getting the mounted disk return self._get_mounted_disk_from_lun(target_iqn, target_lun, wait_for_device=True) mounted_disk_path = self.get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume( connection_info) target_iqn = connection_info['data']['target_iqn'] target_iqn = connection_info['data']['target_iqn'] mounted_disk_path = self.get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume( connection_info) def get_mounted_disk_path_from_volume(self, connection_info): return self._get_disk_path(connection_info)
deleted_lines: if self.ebs_root_in_block_devices(block_device_info): mapping = mapping[1:] disk_address = 0 for vol in mapping: connection_info = vol['connection_info'] volume_driver = self._get_volume_driver( connection_info=connection_info) volume_driver.fix_instance_volume_disk_path( instance_name, connection_info, disk_address) disk_address += 1 data = connection_info['data'] target_lun = data['target_lun'] target_iqn = data['target_iqn'] mounted_disk_path = self._get_mounted_disk_from_lun(target_iqn, target_lun) data = connection_info['data'] target_lun = data['target_lun'] target_iqn = data['target_iqn'] # Getting the mounted disk mounted_disk_path = self._get_mounted_disk_from_lun(target_iqn, target_lun) def fix_instance_volume_disk_path(self, instance_name, connection_info, disk_address): data = connection_info['data'] target_lun = data['target_lun'] target_iqn = data['target_iqn'] mounted_disk_path = self._get_mounted_disk_from_lun( target_iqn, target_lun, True) ctrller_path = self._vmutils.get_vm_scsi_controller(instance_name) self._vmutils.set_disk_host_resource( instance_name, ctrller_path, disk_address, mounted_disk_path) def fix_instance_volume_disk_path(self, instance_name, connection_info, disk_address): self.ensure_share_mounted(connection_info)

commit_message:
HyperV: Set disk serial number for attached volumes

Setting the disk serial number allows us to easily map volumes
with the according virtual disk resources.

This is required for the Fibre Channel support implementation, as
well for the patch fixing the swapped VM disks after host reboot.

Co-Authored-By: Alin Balutoiu <abalutoiu@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Partial-Bug: #1526831
Depends-On: I7faf798aa7c1c306ac641f4364b1407b80b40b09
Change-Id: I5a91c12eb54d8539e30598e617eb9f036fbba843
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/258614/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: serial = connection_info['serial'] mounted_disk_path, serial=serial)

commit_message:
Skip test_volume_backed_live_migration()

This test has been flaky in the neutron multi-node jobs,
both non-DVR and DVR. Let's skip it for now so we can
make progress with live migration work.

Change-Id: I02a147008d5b926a6ad12ffcd4f7dbc308cf6ac7
Related-bug: #1549511

commit_message:
Fix WARNING "No tags for method" list/show/create/deleteSecGroupRule(s)

This patch is an addtional part of patch set 3 on
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/216927/. It fixes the WARNING
"No tags for method" list/show/create/deleteSecGroupRule(s)
when using fairy-slipper to migrate WADL to Swagger.

Change-Id: I3a7ec23630bdefe0019321e569737952eed0d0e0
Closes-Bug: #1482246

commit_message:
Allow tagging physical disk resources with serial numbers

This is needed in order to easily map physical disk resources
attached to instances with the according volumes.

Co-Authored-By: Alin Balutoiu <abalutoiu@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Partial-Bug: #1526831

Change-Id: I7faf798aa7c1c306ac641f4364b1407b80b40b09

commit_message:
Latest

Change-Id: I6c8fbf14dbbf5e8f25f023a92cf435e4ea161b56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-specs refs/changes/13/284813/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Murano is a multi-tenant solution that is well integrated with the OpenStack. In particular Murano neither deals with authentication and authorization nor asks user for a password or other credentials. Instead it relies on OpenStack dashboard to provide Murano with a Keystone token that can be used to further authenticate to other OpenStack services during deployment time. However Keystone token is no help for deployment on other platforms. So for cases where the target cloud is not the one Murano runs in authentication must become a part of the Murano workflow and part of the user input. This also implies that the policies must affect user input as well because different cloud platforms may require different input fields and different processing. The configurations of target clouds (including the access credentials) should become first-class Murano objects, accessible in MuranoPL as properties of cloud-affiliated classes (applications, VMs etc). In future, such configuration objects should be creatable using regular generic Murano tooling, but for now we may have a set of custom DB tables to store them, API methods to access and modify and UI forms to interact with them. Instance Credentials to access the Virtual Machines that are launched. - This would be required to support SSH as a transport mechanism to get the execution plan to the Murano Agent or - Execute the plan using SSH as a transport mechanism ala the Ansible Way, agentless approach to implementing the execution plan A Cloud Credentials entity will be introduced in the MURANO data model. ThisA Cloud Instance Credentials entity will be introduced in the MURANO data murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "id", ID) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "name", varchar) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "tenant_id", varchar) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "user", varchar) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "password", varchar) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "key_pair", varchar) murano:property(cloud_instance_credential, "cloud_type", varchar) "cloud_type" : "cloud_type", "cloud_type" : "cloud_type",#. While processing the environment create post, We need to embed the cloud credential name in the environment description. It would be access to the murano engine can query. instance-credential.` - Instance cloud credential access.#. specs/newton/multi-cloud-capable-murano-core-library.rst #. Murano Mutli Cloud Support Document
deleted_lines: A Cloud Credentials entity will be introduced in the MURANO object model. ThisA Cloud Instance Credentials entity will be introduced in the MURANO object murano:property(cloud_credential, "id", ID) murano:property(cloud_credential, "name", varchar) murano:property(cloud_credential, "tenant_id", varchar) murano:property(cloud_credential, "user", varchar) murano:property(cloud_credential, "password", varchar) murano:property(cloud_credential, "key_pair", varchar)#. While processing the environment create post, we need to embed the cloud credentials in the environment description (TBD). It would be access to the murano engine / instance can access it. instance-credential. TODO - Instance cloud credential access. #TBD(Govardhan)TBD
