commit_message:
Migrate datasource create/delete to DSE2

Moved datasource creation/deletion into dsenode.

Change-Id: I6b248a28fa629f2d87e7c715cf7ceefee7212758
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/38/282838/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six import traceback import json from oslo_db import exception as db_excfrom oslo_utils import uuidutils from oslo_utils import importutils from congress.datasources import constants from congress.db import datasources as datasources_db from congress.db import api as db # load configured drivers self.loaded_drivers = self.load_drivers() """Return all local service objects.""" def get_global_service_names(self): """Return names of all services on all nodes.""" local_services = [s['service_id'] for s in self._services] # Also, check services registered on other nodes peer_nodes = self.dse_status()['peers'] for node in peer_nodes.values(): peer_services = [srv['service_id'] for srv in node['services']] return set(local_services.append(peer_services)) # Datasource CRUD. Maybe belongs in a subclass of DseNode? def load_drivers(self): """Load all configured drivers and check no name conflict""" result = {} print("conf.drivers: %s" % cfg.CONF.drivers) for driver_path in cfg.CONF.drivers: obj = importutils.import_class(driver_path) driver = obj.get_datasource_info() if driver['id'] in result: raise BadConfig(_("There is a driver loaded already with the" "driver name of %s") % driver['id']) driver['module'] = driver_path result[driver['id']] = driver print("result: %s" % result) return result def get_datasources(self, filter_secret=False): """Return the created datasources as recorded in the DB. This returns what datasources the database contains, not the datasources that this server instance is running. """ results = [] for datasource in datasources_db.get_datasources(): result = self.make_datasource_dict(datasource) if filter_secret: # secret field may be not provided while creating datasource # TODO(dse2): seems weird that we're both pulling from the DB # and RPCing into every datasource. Why? datasource_info = self.rpc(result['id'], 'get_datasource_info') try: hides = datasource_info['secret'] for hide_field in hides: result['config'][hide_field] = "<hidden>" except KeyError: pass results.append(result) return results def make_datasource_dict(self, req, fields=None): result = {'id': req.get('id') or uuidutils.generate_uuid(), 'name': req.get('name'), 'driver': req.get('driver'), 'description': req.get('description'), 'type': None, 'enabled': req.get('enabled', True)} # NOTE(arosen): we store the config as a string in the db so # here we serialize it back when returning it. if isinstance(req.get('config'), six.string_types): result['config'] = json.loads(req['config']) else: result['config'] = req.get('config') return self._fields(result, fields) def _fields(self, resource, fields): if fields: return dict(((key, item) for key, item in resource.items() if key in fields)) return resource def add_datasource(self, item, deleted=False, update_db=True): req = self.make_datasource_dict(item) # If update_db is True, new_id will get a new value from the db. new_id = req['id'] driver_info = self.get_driver_info(item['driver']) session = db.get_session() try: with session.begin(subtransactions=True): LOG.debug("adding datasource %s", req['name']) if update_db: LOG.debug("updating db") datasource = datasources_db.add_datasource( id_=req['id'], name=req['name'], driver=req['driver'], config=req['config'], description=req['description'], enabled=req['enabled'], session=session) new_id = datasource['id'] self.validate_create_datasource(req) if self.is_valid_service(req['name']): raise DatasourceNameInUse(value=req['name']) try: self.create_service( class_path=driver_info['module'], kwargs={'name': req['name'], 'args': item['config']}) # TODO(dse2): figure out how to set the schema # service = cage.service_object(req['name']) # engine.set_schema(req['name'], service.get_schema()) except Exception: raise DatasourceCreationError(value=req['name']) except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: raise DatasourceNameInUse(value=req['name']) new_item = dict(item) new_item['id'] = new_id return self.make_datasource_dict(new_item) def validate_create_datasource(self, req): driver = req['driver'] config = req['config'] or {} for loaded_driver in self.loaded_drivers.values(): if loaded_driver['id'] == driver: specified_options = set(config.keys()) valid_options = set(loaded_driver['config'].keys()) # Check that all the specified options passed in are # valid configuration options that the driver exposes. invalid_options = specified_options - valid_options if invalid_options: raise InvalidDriverOption(invalid_options=invalid_options) # check that all the required options are passed in required_options = set( [k for k, v in loaded_driver['config'].items() if v == constants.REQUIRED]) missing_options = required_options - specified_options if missing_options: missing_options = ', '.join(missing_options) raise MissingRequiredConfigOptions( missing_options=missing_options) return loaded_driver # If we get here no datasource driver match was found. raise InvalidDriver(driver=req) def get_driver_info(self, driver): driver = self.loaded_drivers.get(driver) if not driver: raise DriverNotFound(id=driver) return driver def create_service(self, class_path, kwargs): """Create a new DataService on this node. :param name is the name of the service. Must be unique across all services :param classPath is a string giving the path to the class name, e.g. congress.datasources.fake_datasource.FakeDataSource :param args is the list of arguments to give the DataService constructor :param type_ is the kind of service :param id_ is an optional parameter for specifying the uuid. """ # TODO(dse2): fix logging. Want to show kwargs, but hide passwords. # self.log_info("creating service %s with class %s and args %s", # name, moduleName, strutils.mask_password(args, "****")) # split class_path into module and class name pieces = class_path.split(".") module_name = ".".join(pieces[:-1]) class_name = pieces[-1] # import the module try: module = importutils.import_module(module_name) service = getattr(module, class_name)(*kwargs) self.register_service(service) except Exception: # TODO(dse2): add logging for service creation failure raise DataServiceError( "Error loading instance of module '%s':: \n%s" % (class_path, traceback.format_exc())) class DataServiceError (Exception): pass class BadConfig(exception.BadRequest): pass class DatasourceDriverException(exception.CongressException): pass class MissingRequiredConfigOptions(BadConfig): msg_fmt = _("Missing required config options: %(missing_options)s") class InvalidDriver(BadConfig): msg_fmt = _("Invalid driver: %(driver)s") class InvalidDriverOption(BadConfig): msg_fmt = _("Invalid driver options: %(invalid_options)s") class DatasourceNameInUse(exception.Conflict): msg_fmt = _("Datasource already in use with name %(value)s") class DatasourceNotFound(exception.NotFound): msg_fmt = _("Datasource not found %(id)s") class DriverNotFound(exception.NotFound): msg_fmt = _("Driver not found %(id)s") class DatasourceCreationError(BadConfig): msg_fmt = _("Datasource could not be created on the DSE: %(value)s")
deleted_lines: def get_loaded_drivers(self): curr_drivers = [s['service_id'] for s in self._services] # Also, check services registered on other nodes status = self.dse_status()['peers'] for s in status.values(): peer_services = [srv['service_id'] for srv in s['services']] return set(curr_drivers.append(peer_services))

commit_message:
Docs: Keystone AD/LDAP cleanup

This patch cleans up the Keystone AD/LDAP back end section a bit
and adds an additional example where the LDAP back end is used as
a read-only resource.

Change-Id: I9b75d941d7aff4dcafd8e8f486e406455721340d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/83/281883/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Implementing LDAP (or Active Directory) Back ends ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Deployers that already have LDAP or Active Directory (AD) infrastructure deployed can use the built-in Keystone support for those identity services. Keystone can use the existing users, groups and user-group relationships to handle authentication and access control in an OpenStack deployment. .. note:: Although deployers can configure the default domain in Keystone to use LDAP or AD identity back ends, **this is not recommended**. Deployers should create an additional domain in Keystone and configure an LDAP/AD back end for that domain. This is critical in situations where the identity back end cannot be reached due to network issues or other problems. In those situations, the administrative users in the default domain would still be able to authenticate to keystone using the default domain which is not backed by LDAP or AD. In the following example, general users and administrative users are retrieved from different LDAP back ends. .. code-block:: yaml keystone_ldap: Users: url: "ldap://10.10.10.10" user: "root" password: "secrete" ... Admins: url: "ldap://20.20.20.20" user: "root" password: "secrete" ...* keystone.Users.conf * keystone.Admins.confkey-value pairs for the ``[ldap]`` section in the configuration file. The following example uses an LDAP back end as a read-only resource: .. code-block:: yaml keystone_ldap: MyCorporation: url: "ldaps://ldap.example.com" user_tree_dn: "ou=Users,o=MyCorporation" group_tree_dn: "cn=openstack-users,ou=Users,o=MyCorporation" user_objectclass: "inetOrgPerson" user_allow_create: "False" user_allow_update: "False" user_allow_delete: "False" group_allow_create: "False" group_allow_update: "False" group_allow_delete: "False" user_id_attribute: "cn" user_name_attribute: "uid" user_filter: "(groupMembership=cn=openstack-users,ou=Users,o=MyCorporation)" In the *MyCorporation* example above, Keystone will use the LDAP server as a read-only resource. The configuration also ensures that Keystone filters the list of possible users to the ones that exist in the ``cn=openstack-users,ou=Users,o=MyCorporation`` group.
deleted_lines: Implementing LDAP (or AD) Back-Ends ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ In many environments there may already be a LDAP (or Active Directory) service available which already has Users, Groups and User-Group assignment data. Keystone can be configured to make use of the LDAP service using Domain-specific Back-End configuration. While it is possible to set the Keystone Identity Back-End to use LDAP for the Default domain, this is not recommended. It is a better practice to use the Default domain for service accounts and to configure additional Domains for LDAP services which provide general User/Group data. Example implementation in user_variables.yml: keystone_ldap: Users: url: "ldap://10.10.10.10" user: "root" password: "secrete" ... Admins: url: "ldap://20.20.20.20" user: "root" password: "secrete" ... - keystone.Users.conf - keystone.Admins.confkey-value pairs for the 'ldap' section in the configuration file.

commit_message:
Follow-up on PyMySQL support for Red Hat platforms

Rely on packaging dependencies to avoid issues caused by different
package names between Fedora and RHEL (python-PyMySQL vs
python2-PyMySQL).

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/245229/4/spec/classes/neutron_db_spec.rb
includes all the discussion that led to this.

Change-Id: I6ba84a2636411a0be76603d47ca09ee4c93fbfe6
(cherry picked from commit bd64e9274b33e89814a223240f3c954a71c8bca3)

commit_message:
Add tempest logging to bay_client and test_bay helper methods

This patch will add tempest logs to bay_client and
test_bay helper methods to provide ability in debugging
gate issues as well as ability to run analysis on logs

Closes-Bug: 1545124
Change-Id: Id5bda1a8776c29ec7cbe2366b3139358811b57c7

commit_message:
Remove pandoc from bindep-fallback.txt

pandoc was used in the past for building identity-api and image-api,
these are now retired.

A search using codesearch.openstack.org shows only a usage in terracotta
and that one is not invoked anywhere in infra scripts.

Corresponding change for system-config:
I83050f32dd45330831e01c9828ff75a924469f82

Change-Id: Id2e2278e160fa22e75ffbc15a8f9e233c9eeb7e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/70/284370/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Refactor scaling policy implementation

This patch reworks the scaling policy v1.0 to use common utility
functions for parameter validation. Another change made is about whether
we count ERROR nodes when doing scaling. Previously, we exclude them
when calculating current size. However, that might be wrong. We should
always do things consistently.

Change-Id: I98deb8a6136698dbb46630b75e7c21dd5440c4d9

commit_message:
Fix LB/Listener status updates for HM/Member

Recent scenario tests are showing create operations on
pool-subordinate objects (like Member and Health Monitor) appear
to be returning too quickly with statuses that indictate the
operation is done. This has lead to intermittent problems of tests
failing because the load balancer was not in an expected state.

Our hypothesis is that the aforementioned operations are not
setting the load balancer status to PENDING_UPDATE as they should.
This patch fixes this problem, ensuring that PENDING_UPDATE status
is set on the load balancer and listener status correctly prior to
the execution of the creation taskflow, as well as whenever pool or
pool-subordinate objects are updated and deleted. This should resolve
the related intermittent scenario test failures.

In addition to the above, I have re-organized some of the API methods
to remove some code duplication between various API controller, and
re-organized several of the API functional tests for health monitors
and members to catch the above problem.

Change-Id: I5e3a1eabb76af3b913e3edbe95a3b14c3c40244b
Closes-Bug: 1548588

subject: BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrAgent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-30 21:10:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4a6b37408e813dfda0f75fe8a51be99fcff31fc6', 'message': '[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce dragent agent

Dynamic routing needs a new agent that will host the BgpSpeaker driver
and will do the actual communication between the BgpPeers via a BgpSpeaker.
This agent will take information from a single BgpSpeaker entity,
that has all the information that the agent needs to do the routing
exchange: peers and routes. In this approach, an agent can only host one
BgpSpeaker to avoid conflicts.

HA feature (two agents hosting the same routing instance) has to be done manually.

Outstanding Items:
- Unit testcases
- Few RPC Interface implementation
- Manual agent scheduling/unscheduling for BgpPeers

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-11 07:55:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2a9bf2309144564372fe5f1ebc67040ae43c9128', 'message': '[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce drgent

This patch implements a new agent named "BGP DRAgent".
The new agent will host different BGP speaking drivers
and makes the required BGP peering session/s for
neutron. The agent takes the needed "peer/s and route/s"
information from the BGP speaker entity and synchronize
the same to registerd driver.

Note:
 - In this approach, an agent can only host one
   BGP speaker to avoid conflicts.
 - For achieving HA, two dragents should host same
   BGP speaker. This needs to ensured manually.

Outstanding Items:
- Unit testcases.
- Manual scheduling/unscheduling of peers and routes.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2015-08-26 21:38:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/498b383f65cebd65f4e89eca28b89ee742fcb2a9', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce drgent

This patch implements a new agent named "BGP DRAgent". The new agent
will host different BGP speaking drivers and makes the required BGP
peering session/s for neutron. The agent takes the needed "peer/s and
route/s" information from the BGP speaker entity and synchronize the
same to the registerd driver.

Note:
 - In this approach, an agent can only host one BGP speaker to avoid
   conflicts.
 - For achieving HA, two dragents should host same BGP speaker. This
   needs to ensured manually.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d

'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2015-09-26 08:53:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f5a0fbe6fb0aa26385d0f7d2ccca83f2c6854d31', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrAgent

This patch implements a new agent named "BgpDrAgent". The new agent
will host different BGP speaking drivers and makes the required BGP
peering session/s for neutron. The agent takes the needed "peer/s and
route/s" information from the BGP speaker entity and synchronize the
same to the registerd driver.

Important Hightlights:
 - One BgpDrAgent can host multiple BGP speakers.
 - For realizing HA, two BgpDrAgents should host the same BGP speaker.
 - BgpDrAgent queries the registed driver for their maximum BGP speakers
   support and provide an interface to pass this information to the
   neutron server which is required for effective scheduling.

Outestanding Items:
 - API tests.
 - Notify BgpDrScheduler about the maximum speaker support.
 - Provide interfaces for passing BGP speaker and Peer statistics to
   the neutron server.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d

For realizing HA, two BgpDrAgents should host the same BGP speaker.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d
'}, {'number': 30, 'created': '2016-01-12 23:39:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/40ab863b9af41f1ec691669dad269bf752c4cba0', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrAgent

This patch implements a new agent named "BgpDrAgent". The new agent
will host different BGP speaking drivers and makes the required BGP
peering session/s for neutron. The agent takes the needed "peer/s and
route/s" information from the BGP speaker entity and synchronize the
same to the registerd driver.

Important Hightlights:
 - One BgpDrAgent can host multiple BGP speakers.
 - For realizing HA, two BgpDrAgents should host the same BGP speaker.
 - BgpDrAgent queries the registed driver for their multiple BGP speakers
   support and provide an interface to pass this information to the
   neutron server which is required for effective scheduling.

Outestanding Items:
 - API tests.
 - Notify BgpDrScheduler about the maximum speaker support.
 - Provide interfaces for passing BGP speaker and Peer statistics to
   the neutron server.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d

commit_message:
BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrAgent

This patch implements a new agent named "BgpDrAgent". The new agent
will host different BGP speaking drivers and makes the required BGP
peering session/s for neutron. The agent takes the needed "peer/s and
route/s" information from the BGP speaker entity and synchronize the
same to the registerd driver.

For realizing HA, two BgpDrAgents should host the same BGP speaker.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3217795bdd0fa2d9d4b39274f4f95fc013c8d29d

Change-Id: Id5bab4aa627f06e023839290a1d3f46c09890bf8

commit_message:
Ensure to compile translation catalogs

A working directory in DevStack is not trove-dashboard directory,
so the directory path must be specified by an absolute path.

When I tested the devstack plugin for translation previously,
it seems compiled message catalogs existed and I didn't notice it.

Change-Id: Id5bab4aa627f06e023839290a1d3f46c09890bf8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-dashboard refs/changes/09/283709/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -d ${TROVE_DASHBOARD_DIR}/trove_dashboard/locale ]; then (cd ${TROVE_DASHBOARD_DIR}/trove_dashboard; DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=openstack_dashboard.settings ../manage.py compilemessages)

commit_message:
Handle Instance Exceptions in add_fixed_ip and remove_fixed_ip

Instance related exceptions like Instance in Invalidstate and
Instance in Locked state are handled properly when adding or
removing an fixed ip to an instance.

Change-Id: Ifc585e4a909562ab3fbb1dd3c4b4cd2ddf82fd7e
Closes-Bug: #1533260

commit_message:
Remove information about downgrading docker

Since docker 1.10.1 is required, and docker 1.8.2 does not work with Kolla,
Remove the downgrade instructions

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I461572a40b6fc96f73593cf989967449e4bc8e0a
Signed-off-by: Jason Myers <jason@jasonamyers.com>

deleted_lines: note what Kolla releases are not in sync with docker in any way, so some things could stop working with new version. Kolla release 1.0.0-liberty tested to work with docker 1.8.2, to check you docker version run this command:Docker 1.8.3 and later are incompatible with Kolla Liberty. Versions greater than 1.8.2 are functional with master branch (Mitaka). If the version installed is 1.8.3 or later and you are running Liberty, downgrade using these commands: :: # Centos 7 yum downgrade docker-engine-1.8.2 systemctl restart docker.service # Ubuntu 14.04 LTS apt-get install docker-engine=1.8.2-0~trusty

commit_message:
Let Puppet update all packages on non-controllers

With I02f7cf07792765359f19fdf357024d9e48690e42[1] in puppet-tripleo,
puppet is capable of updating all packages itself on non controller
nodes now.

This is a safer mechanism than using the exclude logic in yum_update.sh
since that can cause depdency problems across sub packages.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/261041/
Closes-Bug: 1534785

Change-Id: I9075a1bb85baa65a9d0afc5d0fd31a1f99a98819

deleted_lines: echo "Excluding upgrading packages that are handled by config management tooling" command_arguments="$command_arguments --skip-broken" for exclude in $(cat /var/lib/tripleo/installed-packages/* | sort -u); do command_arguments="$command_arguments --exclude $exclude" done

commit_message:
Rename tox env to pep8

It turns out the linters rename was a bit premature[1].  Use the
current standard pep8 name so we don't need custom jobs in the
gate to run this test on proposed changes.

Change-Id: I5226d4c5e3d4095d76cba24fcf27f87c59730587
1: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-February/086268.html

commit_message:
Use oslo.config fixture to avoid gate break

With Ibd0566f11df62da031afb128c9687c5e8c7b27ae, we are changing
the oslo.config internals a bit. The code in Heat test suite
unnecesssarily depends on oslo.config internals. Just using
the oslo.config fixture is good enough for these tests. This
will avoid CI failures next week when we make a new release
for oslo.config.

Closes-Bug: #1547612
Change-Id: Ibf784d08fbad099189507ff4f665788aee7a3a97
(cherry picked from commit 803755cfa63690fd3b340f1b2afe6534d24a7d5b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/59/283659/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import fixture as config_fixture self.fixture = self.useFixture(config_fixture.Config()) self.fixture.conf(args=['--config-dir', self.policy_path])
deleted_lines: from oslo_config import cfg self.opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('config_dir', default=self.policy_path), cfg.StrOpt('config_file', default='foo'), cfg.StrOpt('project', default='heat'), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(self.opts) cfg.CONF.set_default('host', 'host') cfg.CONF.unregister_opts(self.opts)

Change-Id: I0e3d99da8c54d2912463ecba7c1783864a7c7fc7
Closes-Bug: #1548833
Closes-Bug: #1506873
'}]
commit_message:
Skip ovs_ and ebtables_dump if needed commands not present

Skip with a notification that a command was not found when trying
to run a dump that relies on optional external command.

Otherwise we produce noise in the error output that is misleading.

Change-Id: I0e3d99da8c54d2912463ecba7c1783864a7c7fc7
Closes-Bug: #1548833
Closes-Bug: #1506873
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/45/283645/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(cdent): If we're not using neutron + ovs these commands # will not be present so if subprocess.call(['which', 'ovs-vsctl']) != 0: return

commit_message:
API Services for Flavors Panel

Adding the api services needed by the flavor panel
for the sub flows

To test set DISABLED = False in _2081_admin_flavors_panel.py

Co-Authored-By: Rajat Vig <rajatv@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Errol Pais <epais@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kristine Brown <kbrown@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kyle Olivo <keolivo@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Yakira Dixon <ydixon@thoughtworks.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dan Siwiec <dsiwiec@thoughtworks.com>

Change-Id: Iad97739203a05cce3c971cc8458cd2eb67e117d3
Partially-Implements: blueprint ng-flavors

commit_message:
localize user/project variables in tempest

lib/tempest is using / setting a ton of globals, a lot which don't
look used. As a first step to converting over to s/tenant/project/
make all of these local which means they can not be impacting anything
outside of this function. That will make them safe to change names
later.

Change-Id: I380dd20e5ed716a0bdf92aa02c3730359b8136e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/88/281788/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local password=${ADMIN_PASSWORD:-secrete} local admin_username=${ADMIN_USERNAME:-admin} local admin_tenant_name=${ADMIN_TENANT_NAME:-admin} local admin_domain_name=${ADMIN_DOMAIN_NAME:-Default} local tempest_username=${TEMPEST_USERNAME:-demo} local tempest_tenant_name=${TEMPEST_TENANT_NAME:-demo} local alt_username=${ALT_USERNAME:-alt_demo} local alt_tenant_name=${ALT_TENANT_NAME:-alt_demo} local admin_tenant_id=$(openstack project list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_username $admin_username iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_tenant_name $admin_tenant_name iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_tenant_id $admin_tenant_id iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_domain_name $admin_domain_name local service local tempest_services="key,glance,nova,neutron,cinder,swift,heat,ceilometer,horizon,sahara,ironic,trove" for service in ${tempest_services//,/ }; do tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $admin_username --os-password $admin_password --os-tenant-name $admin_tenant_name -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY --with-admin etc/accounts.yaml tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $admin_username --os-password $admin_password --os-tenant-name $admin_tenant_name -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY etc/accounts.yaml
deleted_lines: password=${ADMIN_PASSWORD:-secrete} ADMIN_USERNAME=${ADMIN_USERNAME:-admin} ADMIN_TENANT_NAME=${ADMIN_TENANT_NAME:-admin} ADMIN_DOMAIN_NAME=${ADMIN_DOMAIN_NAME:-Default} TEMPEST_USERNAME=${TEMPEST_USERNAME:-demo} TEMPEST_TENANT_NAME=${TEMPEST_TENANT_NAME:-demo} ALT_USERNAME=${ALT_USERNAME:-alt_demo} ALT_TENANT_NAME=${ALT_TENANT_NAME:-alt_demo} ADMIN_TENANT_ID=$(openstack project list | awk "/ admin / { print \$2 }") iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_username $ADMIN_USERNAME iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_tenant_name $ADMIN_TENANT_NAME iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_tenant_id $ADMIN_TENANT_ID iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth admin_domain_name $ADMIN_DOMAIN_NAME TEMPEST_SERVICES="key,glance,nova,neutron,cinder,swift,heat,ceilometer,horizon,sahara,ironic,trove" for service in ${TEMPEST_SERVICES//,/ }; do tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $ADMIN_USERNAME --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD --os-tenant-name $ADMIN_TENANT_NAME -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY --with-admin etc/accounts.yaml tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $ADMIN_USERNAME --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD --os-tenant-name $ADMIN_TENANT_NAME -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY etc/accounts.yaml

commit_message:
Refactor health manager for future work

This patch is about a revision to the health manager (service). It adds
to the health manager a thread pool that can be used for cluster status
monitoring.

Change-Id: Iaaebe80a34ee4ae0f636342ebc27231c6f312db9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/93/284193/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # create a dispatcher RPC service for this engine. # create a health manager RPC service for this engine. self.health_mgr = health_manager.HealthManager( self, self.health_mgr_topic, consts.RPC_API_VERSION)
deleted_lines: # create a dispatcher greenthread for this engine. # create a health manager greenthread for this engine. self.health_mgr = health_manager.Health_Manager(self, self.health_mgr_topic, consts.RPC_API_VERSION, self.TG)

commit_message:
Add stack hook poll and clear to openstack client

Refactor existing hook helper fuctions into utilites.

based upon heat clis:
   heat hook-poll
   hest hook-clear

Change-Id: Ib46634cc62369fb5932dcd0967ae492446c79a88
Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/56/252656/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heatclient.common import event_utils from heatclient.common import hook_utilsfrom heatclient.v1 import events class TestStackHookPoll(TestStack): columns = ['ID', 'Resource Status Reason', 'Resource Status', 'Event Time'] event1 = events.Event(manager=None, info={ 'resource_name': 'resource1', 'event_time': '2015-12-02T19:59:58', 'logical_resource_id': 'resource1', 'resource_status': 'INIT_COMPLETE', 'resource_status_reason': 'CREATE paused until Hook pre-create is cleared', 'id': '1111' }) row1 = ('resource1', '1111', 'CREATE paused until Hook pre-create is cleared', 'INIT_COMPLETE', '2015-12-02T19:59:58') event2 = events.Event(manager=None, info={ 'event_time': '2015-12-02T19:59:58', 'logical_resource_id': 'resource2', 'resource_status': 'INIT_COMPLETE', 'resource_status_reason': 'CREATE paused until Hook pre-create is cleared', 'id': '2222' }) row2 = ('resource2', '2222', 'CREATE paused until Hook pre-create is cleared', 'INIT_COMPLETE', '2015-12-02T19:59:58') def setUp(self): super(TestStackHookPoll, self).setUp() self.cmd = stack.StackHookPoll(self.app, None) def test_hook_poll(self): expected_columns = ['Resource Name'] + self.columns expected_rows = [self.row1] hook_utils.get_hook_type_via_status = mock.Mock( return_value='pre-create') event_utils.get_hook_events = mock.Mock( return_value=[self.event1]) arglist = ['my_stack'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, rows = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.assertEqual(expected_columns, columns) self.assertEqual(expected_rows, list(rows)) def test_hook_poll_nested(self): expected_columns = ['Resource Name'] + self.columns + ['Stack Name'] expected_rows = [self.row1 + ('',)] hook_utils.get_hook_type_via_status = mock.Mock( return_value='pre-create') event_utils.get_hook_events = mock.Mock( return_value=[self.event1]) arglist = ['my_stack', '--nested-depth=10'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, rows = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.assertEqual(expected_columns, columns) self.assertEqual(expected_rows, list(rows)) def test_hook_poll_nested_invalid(self): arglist = ['my_stack', '--nested-depth=ugly'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.assertRaises(exc.CommandError, self.cmd.take_action, parsed_args) def test_hook_poll_logical(self): expected_columns = ['Logical Resource ID'] + self.columns expected_rows = [self.row2] hook_utils.get_hook_type_via_status = mock.Mock( return_value='pre-create') event_utils.get_hook_events = mock.Mock( return_value=[self.event2]) arglist = ['my_stack'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, rows = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.assertEqual(expected_columns, columns) self.assertEqual(expected_rows, list(rows)) class TestStackHookClear(TestStack): def setUp(self): super(TestStackHookClear, self).setUp() self.cmd = stack.StackHookClear(self.app, None) hook_utils.clear_wildcard_hooks = mock.Mock() def test_hook_clear(self): hook_utils.get_hook_type_via_status = mock.Mock( return_value='pre-create') arglist = ['my_stack', 'resource'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) hook_utils.clear_wildcard_hooks.assert_called_once_with( self.mock_client, 'my_stack', [], 'pre-create', 'resource') def test_hook_clear_pre_create(self): arglist = ['my_stack', 'resource', '--pre-create'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) hook_utils.clear_wildcard_hooks.assert_called_once_with( self.mock_client, 'my_stack', [], 'pre-create', 'resource') def test_hook_clear_pre_update(self): arglist = ['my_stack', 'resource', '--pre-update'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) hook_utils.clear_wildcard_hooks.assert_called_once_with( self.mock_client, 'my_stack', [], 'pre-update', 'resource')

This commit copies some basic structure and code from the Kilo branch in
order to facilitate upgrading between Kilo and Liberty. It is *not*
intended to massively overhaul the upgrade process; rather, it is meant
to provide a functional method of moving to the newer version.

Added is support for changing Nova 2.1 variable names. See Change
Ie5a42059c10e7fd0bfc4dba8d87dea3f32db968e / commit
dd69ff9e01532140d8acad2e4223f7d83c25cc1f for details.

Also added is support for updated heat keystone configuration. See
Change 7d3768a5629bb202883e82fe0c9c52fb0ca38b97 / commit
c12e7397b237c1adac8f0fb56ff0e5157ab16402

/etc/openstack_deploy will be copied to /etc/openstack_deploy.KILO for
the upgrade, in case any configuration changes get lost.

The aodh and haproxy environment files are copied to the
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d directory. The ceilometer and neutron files
are modified to remove and add entries, respectively. These are
modified, rather than copied, in order to preserve any user changes to
the environment.

Change-Id: Ie512e6fab138d0bcc8b8c31b0620d4ecdf4a8d87

This commit copies some basic structure and code from the Kilo branch in
order to facilitate upgrading between Kilo and Liberty. It is *not*
intended to massively overhaul the upgrade process; rather, it is meant
to provide a functional method of moving to the newer version.

Added is support for changing Nova 2.1 variable names. See Change
Ie5a42059c10e7fd0bfc4dba8d87dea3f32db968e / commit
dd69ff9e01532140d8acad2e4223f7d83c25cc1f for details.

Change 7d3768a5629bb202883e82fe0c9c52fb0ca38b97 / commit
c12e7397b237c1adac8f0fb56ff0e5157ab16402

Environment modification is done within an ansible playbook to take
advantage of the idempotency for actions like copying files.

/etc/openstack_deploy will be copied to /etc/openstack_deploy.KILO for
the upgrade, in case any configuration changes get lost. The script will
look for this directory before doing any work, and exit if it is
present.

The aodh and haproxy environment files are copied to the
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d directory. The ceilometer and neutron files
are modified to remove and add entries, respectively. These are
modified, rather than copied, in order to preserve any user changes to
the environment.

Change-Id: Ie512e6fab138d0bcc8b8c31b0620d4ecdf4a8d87

This commit copies some basic structure and code from the Kilo branch in
order to facilitate upgrading between Kilo and Liberty. It is *not*
intended to massively overhaul the upgrade process; rather, it is meant
to provide a functional method of moving to the newer version.

Added is support for changing Nova 2.1 variable names. See Change
Ie5a42059c10e7fd0bfc4dba8d87dea3f32db968e / commit
dd69ff9e01532140d8acad2e4223f7d83c25cc1f for details.

Also added is support for updated heat keystone configuration. See
Change 7d3768a5629bb202883e82fe0c9c52fb0ca38b97 / commit
c12e7397b237c1adac8f0fb56ff0e5157ab16402

Environment modification is done within an ansible playbook to take
advantage of the idempotency for actions like copying files.

/etc/openstack_deploy will be copied to /etc/openstack_deploy.KILO for
the upgrade, in case any configuration changes get lost. The script will
look for this directory before doing any work, and exit if it is
present.

The aodh and haproxy environment files are copied to the
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d directory. The ceilometer and neutron files
are modified to remove and add entries, respectively. These are
modified, rather than copied, in order to preserve any user changes to
the environment. The scripts are idempotent.

Change-Id: Ie512e6fab138d0bcc8b8c31b0620d4ecdf4a8d87
'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2016-02-22 22:42:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/83dd708feea477af623a4d654e80a9908b5a5afc', 'message': '[WIP] Add support for upgrading from Kilo to Liberty

c12e7397b237c1adac8f0fb56ff0e5157ab16402

Environment modification is done within an ansible playbook to take
advantage of the idempotency for actions like copying files.

/etc/openstack_deploy will be copied to /etc/openstack_deploy.KILO for
the upgrade, in case any configuration changes get lost. The script will
look for this directory before doing any work, and exit if it is
present.

The aodh and haproxy environment files are copied to the
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d directory. The ceilometer and neutron files
are modified to remove and add entries, respectively. These are
modified, rather than copied, in order to preserve any user changes to
the environment. The scripts are idempotent.

Change-Id: Ie512e6fab138d0bcc8b8c31b0620d4ecdf4a8d87

commit_message:
[WIP] Add support for upgrading from Kilo to Liberty

This commit copies some basic structure and code from the Kilo branch in
order to facilitate upgrading between Kilo and Liberty. It is *not*
intended to massively overhaul the upgrade process; rather, it is meant
to provide a functional method of moving to the newer version.

Added is support for changing Nova 2.1 variable names. See Change
Ie5a42059c10e7fd0bfc4dba8d87dea3f32db968e / commit
dd69ff9e01532140d8acad2e4223f7d83c25cc1f for details.

Also added is support for updated heat keystone configuration. See
Change 7d3768a5629bb202883e82fe0c9c52fb0ca38b97 / commit
c12e7397b237c1adac8f0fb56ff0e5157ab16402

Environment modification is done within an ansible playbook to take
advantage of the idempotency for actions like copying files.

/etc/openstack_deploy will be copied to /etc/openstack_deploy.KILO for
the upgrade, in case any configuration changes get lost. The various
components of the script will use flag files in this directory in order
to use ansible's idempotent features.

The aodh and haproxy environment files are copied to the
/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d directory. The ceilometer and neutron files
are modified to remove and add entries, respectively. These are
modified, rather than copied, in order to preserve any user changes to
the environment. The scripts are idempotent.

Change-Id: Ie512e6fab138d0bcc8b8c31b0620d4ecdf4a8d87

commit_message:
make microversion a client level construct for tests

Instead of passing around microversion in every method call, the way
microversions are expected to be used by a client is by setting it
globally for the client and using that microversion for all requests.

This adds that support to the base test client, and updates nearly all
tests to use it that way. test_server_group is tightly coupled and
will require some much more specific unwind.

Change-Id: I2263104c34328f11c687c6b8ef3a1cfd21980a63

commit_message:
Add test_router integration test

Create both test for router create/delete and router Page Object. Also
decapitalize routers table name so it could be referenced in
integration tests like any other table.

Change-Id: Ic4fdfa82584dd3cad1e906d5fc5526c4a758675f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/260360/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests import helpers from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests.tests import decorators class TestRouters(helpers.TestCase): ROUTER_NAME = helpers.gen_random_resource_name("router") NETWORK_NAME = "public" @decorators.services_required("neutron") def test_router_create(self): """tests the router creation and deletion functionalities: * creates a new router for public network * verifies the router appears in the routers table as active * deletes the newly created router * verifies the router does not appear in the table after deletion """ routers_page = self.home_pg.go_to_router_routerspage() routers_page.create_router(self.ROUTER_NAME, self.NETWORK_NAME) self.assertTrue(routers_page.is_router_present(self.ROUTER_NAME)) self.assertTrue(routers_page.is_router_active(self.ROUTER_NAME)) routers_page.delete_router(self.ROUTER_NAME) self.assertFalse(routers_page.is_router_present(self.ROUTER_NAME))

commit_message:
Use tempest.lib code in tempest

Now that tempest_lib code is copied back into tempest, stop using
tempest_lib in tempest, and start using the copied code.

Remove the dependency to tempest_lib from requirements, and drop
the script to use tempest_lib in tempest. Add os-testr to the
test-requirements.

Partially implements bp tempest-lib-reintegration

Change-Id: I21ab5fe6349f72c98ac9f960a29bf62e813f8b1b

deleted_lines: from tempest_lib import exceptions as lib_exc

commit_message:
OpenstackClient plugin for software deployment output show

This change implements the "openstack software deployment output show" command

Based from the existing heat command:
    heat deployment-output-show

Change-Id: Ide607c925a15071c0c02c8cdb1ba20d9a745f9a9
Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient

commit_message:
Move _from_db_object() into base class

Had five copies of the def _from_db_object() function in various
classes. Move this function into their common base class.

Change-Id: I543386a708d80f7c89455e556e2abc6d532661b0

added_lines: @staticmethod def _from_db_object(object, db_object): """Converts a database entity to a formal object.""" for field in object.fields: object[field] = db_object[field] object.obj_reset_changes() return object

commit_message:
Convergence replace restriction for type change

This implements replace restrictions when resource
type changes with convergence enabled.

Change-Id: If7a2c7712335bbeaf7acbd257288fb44e02d88ff
Blueprint: stack-update-restrict
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/43/280243/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check_for_convergence_replace(self, restricted_actions): if 'replace' in restricted_actions: ex = exception.ResourceActionRestricted(action='replace') failure = exception.ResourceFailure(ex, self, self.UPDATE) self._add_event(self.UPDATE, self.FAILED, six.text_type(ex)) raise failure else: raise exception.UpdateReplace(self.name) registry = new_stack.env.registry new_res_type = registry.get_class_to_instantiate( restricted_actions = registry.get_rsrc_restricted_actions( self.name) if type(self) is not new_res_type: self._check_for_convergence_replace(restricted_actions)
deleted_lines: new_res_type = new_stack.env.registry.get_class_to_instantiate( if type(self) is not new_res_type: raise exception.UpdateReplace(self.name)

commit_message:
Adding "region and endpoint_type" parameters to barbican_cert_manager.py

When requesting for a barbican client, this change lets you filter based on
region and endpoint_type.

Conflicts:
	neutron_lbaas/common/cert_manager/barbican_auth/barbican_acl.py

closes-bug: 1542014

Change-Id: I78ba726dcd921a6344bfc88c832f19e11fb4d781
(cherry picked from commit d596d513bfff3cdacd73e83ca18cf24d18c811bc)

Minor updates to Tips and Tricks

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Iaf4fe7747e1cf5c04cd37cb30985a75f0b1650e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/67/283267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Kolla ships with several utilities intended to facilitate ease of operation. ``tools/cleanup-containers`` can be used to remove deployed containers from the system. This can be useful when you want to do a clean new deployment. It will preserve the registry and the locally built containers in the registry, but will remove all running Kolla containers from the local Docker daemon. ``tools/cleanup-host`` can be used to remove remnants of network changes triggered on the Docker host when the neutron-agents containers are launched. This can be useful when you want to do a clean new deployment, particularly one changing the network topology. ``tools/cleanup-images`` can be used to remove all Docker images from the local Docker cache. Note: this will remove the registry also.

commit_message:
Check FloatingIP status before SSH in network_v6

This patch adds a check for FloatingIP before the
network_v6 tests checks for SSH connection.

This would provide the details on the failure
if it was due to the FloatingIP setup or due to
infrastructure issue.

Partial-Bug: #1426764
Change-Id: I78491d14c80d7b11bae9cec7f72e0ce9f64ac433

commit_message:
Add docs about failures during evaluation

The operators aren't mindreaders.  Lets throw them a bone about
how to properly evaluate Kolla.  This can probably be expanded
on.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I70d0f6a63417dc9f361d8c14bbb512e1dcc44ed0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/29/283129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Failures -------- Nearly always when Kolla fails, it is caused by Operator error. This can include aborting via CTRL-C the deployment process or globals.yml misconfiguration. One common problem is when Operators set the internal_address which should be a VIP, to the host's IP address. The VIP should be an unused IP address on the Operator's network. If a failure during deployment happpens it nearly always happens during evaluation of the software. When evaluating the software, the Operator is nieve to how Kolla itself operates. Once the operator learns the few configuration options required, it is highly unlikely they will experience a failure in deployment. Deployment should only happen *ONCE*. Running deploy again will result in the same results as the last deploy operation. The kolla community has separate commands planned for reconfiguring the services and upgrading them. The fastest way during evaluation to recover from a deployment failure is to remove the failed deployment: On each node where OpenStack is deployed run: :: tools/cleanup-containers tools/cleanup-host

commit_message:
Use assertIsNone instead of assertEqual(None, ***)

Instead of using assertEqual(None, ***), developers should
use assertIsNone(***).

Change-Id: I55e9161a4df9197546603385228ea85528de43a7
Closes-Bug: #1510006

commit_message:
Ironic: Fix docs & linting tests

Unfortunately the first commit of os_ironic had broken tests. This patch
corrects the test configurations to ensure that the docs and lint tests
work.

As a temporary measure, functional testing is left as a place holder
to allow other patches to be worked on for this role while the functional
testing is being put together.

Change-Id: I38278155232a4e4d6ef259b79bd515fae2bc837b
Signed-off-by: Michael Davies <michael@the-davies.net>
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

commit_message:
Deprecated tox -downloadcache option removed

Caching is enabled by default from pip version 6.0

More info:
https://testrun.org/tox/latest/config.html#confval-downloadcache=path
https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#caching

Change-Id: I3d9cf319804532b2b16d14cbc5ba2621c9b082de

commit_message:
Rename network driver name in Validator class

The reason is:
We added volume driver to the validator so that we need to identify
network driver to make them as clear as them are.

Beside, fix a wrong case in volume driver validatior.

Change-Id: I128fcd3856fba49f0784e90fd6db3d591a7ed7ae

commit_message:
Avoid to create $SCREEN_LOGDIR

It is possible not to give SCREEN_LOGDIR variable in devstack.
And also, SCREEN_LOGDIR is creating in stack.sh itself [1].
So we can remove our code which is creating SCREEN_LOGDIR.
This code breaks stack.sh process if user doesn't give this
variable.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/2688eedc51fc7b4ef0a5332c1aafce8a557928da/stack.sh#L454

Change-Id: I5c6ce81a97635b60fc1633397a24f93dc590fad6
Closes-Bug: #1548197

commit_message:
Pull clustercheck directly from git

This probably shouldn't merge, but I want to see if there are any
other problems with the new mariadb-server that obsoleted the
mariadb-galera-server we were using.  mariadb-server no longer
includes the clustercheck script, so this change should get CI past
that problem and find any subsequent issues.

Adding a Depends-On because a lot of our deployments have been
failing before they even get to the clustercheck step.

Related-Bug: 1547660
Change-Id: I3b0eb70b1cdc782c1a6793c1b616dbe6ee9cb712
Depends-On: I2bcdabbba6a123eccdaee56fa4c8bcc6c74616c7

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-22 22:53:29.000000000', 'files': ['instack_undercloud/undercloud.py', 'instack_undercloud/tests/test_undercloud.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud/commit/47f1522f0345740b121d99f2ad405678f85ffba6', 'message': "Unset DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF before running undercloud install

This variable doesn't make sense in the context of an undercloud
install because we're not in a chroot so there's no reason to copy
repos in.  It also causes a confusing error message when it's set
because it tries to copy files over themselves.  For the sake of
sanity, let's just always unset it.

Change-Id: Ieb500d21828abcf56277ce056c1051d36bf4e460
"}]
commit_message:
Unset DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF before running undercloud install

This variable doesn't make sense in the context of an undercloud
install because we're not in a chroot so there's no reason to copy
repos in.  It also causes a confusing error message when it's set
because it tries to copy files over themselves.  For the sake of
sanity, let's just always unset it.

Change-Id: Ieb500d21828abcf56277ce056c1051d36bf4e460
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/57/271557/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_remove_dib_yum_repo_conf(self): self.useFixture(fixtures.EnvironmentVariable('DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF', 'rum_yepo.conf')) env = undercloud._generate_environment('.') self.assertNotIn(env, 'DIB_YUM_REPO_CONF')

commit_message:
Add experimental-infra-bindep-jobs

In the effort to move to bindep jobs, we are adding more test coverage
using openstack-infra project-config.  The goal here is to get more
tox coverage for envlist that are not in python-jobs JJB group.

Change-Id: I743b18860ba9a6e1a327d1a9a5cb94c9f04de09a
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Reference config values at runtime

Configuration values can be changed at runtime, therefore the
tests should not use the value that was set at import time
since the value might have been changed.

Change-Id: Ib2baa0da12c5b7f13a3f757fb3faea9da3b0c467

HNAS driver has 2 configuration options:
- SSC (ssh_enabled: False ): requires a local utility package
installed to run the commands
- SSH (ssh_enabled: True): Runs the commands using the utility
package installed on HNAS

Currently, the HNAS driver is considering the "ssh_enabled" and the
"cluster_admin_ip0" tags to decide if the command to get the utility
package version should be ran locally or not. This is not correct
because the "cluster_admin_ip0" tag is not mandatory even if the SSH
mode is enabled.
So, if we have a situation that SSH is enabled and the
"cluster_admin_ip0" does not exist in the configuration, the driver
tries to run the command to get the utility package version locally
and its initialization breaks.
This patch makes the driver consider only the "ssh_enabled" tag
value to decide if the command to get the utility package version
is necessary.

commit_message:
HNAS driver: Fix SSH and cluster_admin_ip0 bug

HNAS driver has 2 configuration options:
- SSC (ssh_enabled: False ): requires a local utility package
installed to run the commands
- SSH (ssh_enabled: True): Runs the commands using the utility
package installed on HNAS

Currently, the HNAS driver is considering the "ssh_enabled" and the
"cluster_admin_ip0" tags to decide if the command to get the utility
package version should be ran locally or not. This is not correct
because the "cluster_admin_ip0" tag is not mandatory even if the SSH
mode is enabled.
So, if we have a situation that SSH is enabled and the
"cluster_admin_ip0" does not exist in the configuration, the driver
tries to run the command to get the utility package version locally
and its initialization breaks.
This patch makes the driver consider only the "ssh_enabled" tag
value to decide if the command to get the utility package version
is necessary.

Change-Id: I29fb5d7199e10eafee329dbd4ccef524245fbc28
Closes-Bug: 1543208
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/277495/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :returns: formatted string with version information #If not using SSH, the local utility version can be different from the #one used in HNAS if self.drv_configs['ssh_enabled'] != 'True': out, err = utils.execute(cmd, "-version", check_exit_code=True) util = out.split()[1] out = ("Array_ID: %s (%s) version: %s LU: 256 RG: 0 RG_LU: 0 " "Utility_version: %s" % (hardware, model, ver, util)) else: out = ("Array_ID: %s (%s) version: %s LU: 256 RG: 0 RG_LU: 0 " % (hardware, model, ver))
deleted_lines: :returns: formated string with version information if (self.drv_configs['ssh_enabled'] == 'True' and self.drv_configs['cluster_admin_ip0'] is not None): util = 'SMU ' + cmd else: out, err = utils.execute(cmd, "-version", check_exit_code=True) util = out.split()[1] out = "Array_ID: %s (%s) version: %s LU: 256 RG: 0 RG_LU: 0 \ Utility_version: %s" % (hardware, model, ver, util)

commit_message:
Introduce 'Get Me A Network' for Neutron

Introduce Neutron's auto-allocated-topology feature.

Since there is not yet any Nova integration, we describe it only for
Neutron operators and users for now.

Implements: blueprint get-me-a-network
Closes-bug: #1544383

Change-Id: I29a5b62ba2527811f0d2a5f7775080e566a3c2d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/33/283133/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================== Additional Features =================== Auto-allocation of Network Topologies ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Also known as "**Get Me A Network**". A new capability was added in Mitaka that simplifies the steps of setting up external connectivity for users. The operator must create a default external network and default subnetpools (one for IPv4, or one for IPv6, or one of each). Once these are in place, users can get their auto-allocated topology with one simple command. Enabling the deployment for auto-allocation ------------------------------------------- To use this feature, the neutron service must have the following extensions enabled: * auto-allocated-topology * subnet_allocation * external-net * router The operator must create the resources that will be used for auto-allocation. 1. Set up a default external network Setting up an external network is described in :ref:`L3-routing-and-NAT`. Assuming the external network to be used for the auto-allocation feature is named ``public``, make it the default external network with the following command: .. code-block:: console $ neutron net-update public --is-default=True #. Create default subnetpools The auto-allocation feature requires at least one default subnetpool. One for IPv4, or one for IPv6, or one of each. .. code-block:: console $ neutron subnetpool-create --shared --is-default True\ --pool-prefix 10.0.0.0/24 --default-prefixlen 26 shared-default Created a new subnetpool: +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | address_scope_id | | | default_prefixlen | 26 | | default_quota | | | id | 7923bc31-4ca4-4c95-9ec2-d69b21775ee2 | | ip_version | 4 | | is_default | True | | max_prefixlen | 32 | | min_prefixlen | 8 | | name | shared-default | | prefixes | 10.0.0.0/24 | | shared | True | | tenant_id | 375e91c9dc854aaa8c8fd93f4b24e87c | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ $ neutron subnetpool-create --shared --is-default True\ --pool-prefix 2001:db8:8000::/48 --default-prefixlen 64 default-v6 Created a new subnetpool: +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | address_scope_id | | | default_prefixlen | 64 | | default_quota | | | id | 953b28ab-5afa-42ea-8f44-44bf111672b1 | | ip_version | 6 | | is_default | True | | max_prefixlen | 128 | | min_prefixlen | 64 | | name | default-v6 | | prefixes | 2001:db8:8000::/48 | | shared | True | | tenant_id | 375e91c9dc854aaa8c8fd93f4b24e87c | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ Get Me A Network ---------------- In a deployment where the operator has set up the resources as described above, users can get their auto-allocated network topology as follows: .. code-block:: console $ neutron auto-allocated-topology-show +-----------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-----------+--------------------------------------+ | id | 8b835bfb-cae2-4acc-b53f-c16bb5f9a7d0 | | tenant_id | 3a4e311bcb3545b9b7ad326f93194f8c | +-----------+--------------------------------------+ The id returned by this command is a network which can be used for booting a VM. .. code-block:: console $ nova boot --flavor m1.small --image cirros-0.3.4-x86_64-uec\ --nic net-id=8b835bfb-cae2-4acc-b53f-c16bb5f9a7d0 vm1 The auto-allocated topology for a user never changes. Project resources created by auto-allocation -------------------------------------------- The auto-allocation feature creates one network topology in every project where it is used. The auto-allocated network topology for a project contains the following resources: +--------------------+------------------------------+ |Resource |Name | +--------------------+------------------------------+ |network |auto_allocated_network | +--------------------+------------------------------+ |subnet (IPv4) |auto_allocated_subnet_v4 | +--------------------+------------------------------+ |subnet (IPv6) |auto_allocated_subnet_v6 | +--------------------+------------------------------+ |router |auto_allocated_router | +--------------------+------------------------------+ Limitations ----------- The auto-allocation feature is currently not supported when the the dvr (Distributed Virtual Router) extension is enabled.

subject: Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-14 14:28:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/7ce5188fcfaf5aacd9e34429ff9afe960f998219', 'message': 'Use locking for IpamAvailabilityRange

list_ranges_by_allocation_pool already had locking as a parameter,
but it was ignored.
Adding correct implementation for locking.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-30 15:35:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/25350abd1c28256dd0e2ba590a29784954940157', 'message': "Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange

Existing locking mechanism 'select for update' causes deadlocks
with galera multi-writers and requires restaring entire transaction to
retry.

Replaced locking rows for update with compare-and-swap.
Actually in current implementation it looks ike delete-and-verify.

Once IpamAvailabilityRange got deleted current thread verify count of
deleted rows to make sure that current thread performed actual deleting
from database.
If row is already deleted, then another thread already changed
data current thread fetched from database, so exception is raised.
Exception is catched by wrap_db_retry and ip allocation (fetching
availabity ranges) is restarted.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351

"}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2015-10-06 09:57:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1f8ed30e21193b4401adfef0aac8535bcc3d137c', 'message': "Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange

Existing locking mechanism 'select for update' causes deadlocks
with galera multi-writers and requires restaring entire transaction to
retry.

Replaced locking rows for update with compare-and-swap.
Actually in current implementation it looks like delete-and-verify.

Once IpamAvailabilityRange got deleted current thread verifies count of
deleted rows to make sure that current thread performed actual deleting
from database.

If row is already deleted, then another thread changed
data current thread works with, so RetryRequest is raised.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351

"}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-10-06 14:59:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f0c223ac74cd7de450b4122f0c950c91734c8e69', 'message': 'Update locking for IpamAvailabilityRange

PostgreSQL disallows a select for .. update with a join on an empty
select. Also existent locking mechanism did not take into account Galera
multi-writers case. And lock was missed for list_ranges_by_allocation_pool.

Locking was moved to separate method to prevent failures with
PostgreSQL, so now rows are locked without using join.
Added retry-on-deadlock wrapper on allocate action, to retry in Galera
case. Fixed missed locking for list_ranges_by_allocation_pool.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351

"}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2015-10-08 13:05:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e6e708093e92353c86e827d8d1fe54922d5383a6', 'message': "Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange

Existing locking mechanism 'select for update' causes deadlocks
with galera multi-writers and requires restaring entire transaction to
retry.

Replaced locking rows with compare-and-swap approach.
Compare-and-swap verifies that row was not changed by
another thread before updating/deleting it, so it uses
filter-and-update or filter-and-delete and return count of affected rows.

If count of affected row is less than expected, then another
thread already changed our row and RetryRequest is raised.

Existent retry wrappers for neutron.api.v2.base were updated to restart
transaction if RetryRequest is raised.
Removed retry wrapper from ml2 create_port.

Enabled Reference IPAM Driver by default in this patch to collect CI
results during debugging. To be removed before final commit.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351

commit_message:
Use compare-and-swap for IpamAvailabilityRange

Existing locking mechanism 'select for update' causes
deadlocks with galera multi-writers.
Replaced locking rows with compare-and-swap approach.

Compare-and-swap verifies that row is not changed by
another thread before updating/deleting it.
Filter-and-update and filter-and-delete are used.
They return count of affected rows.
If count of affected row is less than expected,
then another thread already changed our row
and RetryRequest is raised.

Change-Id: I514cae0fa43033433ec2982bcf3726e02e6692bf
Closes-Bug: #1494351
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/223123/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: range_qry = session.query( if locking: range_qry = range_qry.with_lockmode('update') return range_qry

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: testing bindep-based jobs

Change-Id: I283f76f7e368899334015f2c49113c452b8f1ec8

commit_message:
Set AIO host apt sources to use a configured list of components

re: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-February/086000.html

Ubuntu has 4 different 'components' - main, universe, multiverse and
restricted:
 - Main: Officially supported software.
 - Restricted: Supported software that is not available under a completely
               free license.
 - Universe: Community maintained software, i.e. not officially supported
             software.
 - Multiverse: Software that is not free.

Practically speaking there should be nothing particularly useful to
OpenStack-Ansible in Restricted or Multiverse - it's mostly software for
desktop users.

This patch introduces a new variable 'bootstrap_host_apt_components'
which is a list of the components to configure in the apt sources list. The
default list does not include the unnecessary components.

Change-Id: I4171453cd2fb25d8867bb2dc8fc0337eb82d032e

commit_message:
remove python 2.6 trove classifier

OpenStack projects are no longer being tested under Python 2.6, so
remove the trove classifier implying that this project supports 2.6.

Change-Id: I045245f09b474ddfc00ac6c9e886acf60d0a0697

commit_message:
Allocate uuids for aggregates as they are created or loaded

Note that this filters uuid from the aggregate view in the API because we would
need a microversion. That may be a thing in the future (for the 2.x api) but
not something we can do here.

Related to blueprint generic-resource-pools

Change-Id: I45006e546867d348563831986b91a317029a1173

commit_message:
Tolerate roles in context.RequestContext

In Ia575ba803a0fb70f39146bd75d381ed19414bd23, oslo.context
added roles support in the context itself. Once that change
is released in oslo.context and the global requirements has
been updated, we should switch to passing in the roles in
the __init__ parameter. Until then we should set
self.roles *after* the constructor since the constructor
sets the roles to None when the new library gets released.

Closes-Bug: 1549317
Change-Id: Ie28a4144ccac5d6894405ba7f801617376e35c51

commit_message:
remove redundant call to set explicit target

Setting the target multiple times for the group heading is redundant and
introduces issues with doc sets where there is already a title or other
node with the same target id. Remove the call.

Change-Id: Ia024722d05ce8adaa57c58559cb42f2913653bb9
Closes-Bug: #1549106
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Allow the deployer to pick a predefined IP for VIPs

Adds three top-level params to allow the deployer pick a predefined IP
for the InternalApi, Storage and StorageMgmt VIPs. We had this already
for the External network (PublicVirtualFixedIPs) and the ctlplane
network (ControlFixedIPs).

Change-Id: I1509e1888774ffa72445ed681dd8107eec703d64
(cherry picked from commit ff33f2a64e7d0d6350ce11c737016a6dabe8a6fd)

commit_message:
Remove Heat convergence job on Liberty

The convergence job was wrongly introduced in
0556858daf9f240419c0a21f32939f0a981b3382 on liberty. We shouldn't run it
there, so let's remove it.

Change-Id: I7a28420874e62fc59c1d1f825cdce328189a858c

subject: Add TripleO Heat Template Parameters for Neutron Tenant MTU
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-16 18:03:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/336c10b8ce60f87465aca7d11c10c0c527dab9b0', 'message': 'Add TripleO Heat Template Parameters for Neutron Tenant MTU

This change adds the TripleO Heat Parameters and Puppet hieradata
to support setting the MTU for Neutron tenant networks. The veth
devices that get created to serve as the virtual network interfaces
for the VMs get created with an MTU according to these settings:

in /etc/nova/nova.conf:
network_device_mtu = <MTU>

in /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini:
veth_mtu = <MTU>

These settings are related to the NeutronDnsmasqOptions, since
that is typically used to set the MTU through DHCP for VM hosts.

Typically, you would change all three of these settings to use
jumbo frames in VMs. When using tunneling, NeutronTenantMtu
should be set at least 50 bytes smaller than the physical network
MTU in order to make room for tunneling overhead.

Note that the Puppet hieradata output in this change still needs
to be addressed in related Puppet changes, probably to both the
Nova and Neutron Puppet modules.

Change-Id: I38840e082ee01dc3b6fc78e1dd97f53fa4e63039
(cherry picked from commit 55e8f45fb12670f973c099c43fdbaff5b6ee66ff)
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-16 19:10:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/21b2c109e7a9c3f6fd4f9974301641a03dff77a9', 'message': "Add TripleO Heat Template Parameters for Neutron Tenant MTU

This change adds the TripleO Heat Parameters and Puppet hieradata
to support setting the MTU for Neutron tenant networks. A new
parameter, NeutronTenantMtu is introduced, and this gets used for
the NeutronDnsmasqOptions and in Puppet hieradata.

The veth devices that get created to serve as the virtual network
interfaces for the VMs that get created with an MTU according to these
settings:

in /etc/nova/nova.conf on Controllers and Computes:
network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

in /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini
on Controllers and Computes:
veth_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

in /etc/neutron/l3agent.ini on Controllers only:
network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

finally, the NeutronDnsmasqOptions parameter becomes a str_format
that maps the NeutronTenantMtu onto the DHCP options:

parameters:
  NeutronDnsmasqOptions:
    default: 'dhcp-option-force=26,%MTU%'
    description: Dnsmasq options for neutron-dhcp-agent. The default
    value here forces MTU to be set to 1400 to account for the tunnel
    overhead.

Controller:
    [...]
      properties:
        NeutronDnsmasqOptions:
          str_replace:
            template: {get_param: NeutronDnsmasqOptionsFormat}
            params: '%MTU%': {get_param: NeutronTenantMtu}

This will set dnsmasq to serve an MTU via DHCP that matches the
NeutronTenantMtu. Typically, you would change all three of these
settings to use jumbo frames in VMs. When using tunneling,
NeutronTenantMtu should be set at least 50 bytes smaller than the
physical network MTU in order to make room for tunneling overhead.

Note that the Puppet hieradata output in this change still needs to
be addressed in related Puppet changes, probably to both the Nova
and Neutron Puppet modules.

Change-Id: I38840e082ee01dc3b6fc78e1dd97f53fa4e63039
(cherry picked from commit 55e8f45fb12670f973c099c43fdbaff5b6ee66ff)
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-16 20:08:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/d6590ee06739e82946bf501166c4f311c4c24bc8', 'message': "Add TripleO Heat Template Parameters for Neutron Tenant MTU

This change adds the TripleO Heat Parameters and Puppet hieradata
to support setting the MTU for Neutron tenant networks. A new
parameter, NeutronTenantMtu is introduced, and this gets used for
the NeutronDnsmasqOptions and in Puppet hieradata.

The veth devices that get created to serve as the virtual network
interfaces for the VMs that get created with an MTU according to these
settings:

in /etc/nova/nova.conf on Controllers and Computes:
network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

in /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini
on Controllers and Computes:
veth_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

in /etc/neutron/l3agent.ini on Controllers only:
network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

finally, the NeutronDnsmasqOptions parameter becomes a str_format
that maps the NeutronTenantMtu onto the DHCP options:

parameters:
  NeutronDnsmasqOptions:
    default: 'dhcp-option-force=26,%MTU%'
    description: Dnsmasq options for neutron-dhcp-agent. The default
    value here forces MTU to be set to 1400 to account for the tunnel
    overhead.

Controller:
    [...]
      properties:
        NeutronDnsmasqOptions:
          str_replace:
            template: {get_param: NeutronDnsmasqOptions}
            params: '%MTU%': {get_param: NeutronTenantMtu}

This will set dnsmasq to serve an MTU via DHCP that matches the
NeutronTenantMtu. Typically, you would change all three of these
settings to use jumbo frames in VMs. When using tunneling,
NeutronTenantMtu should be set at least 50 bytes smaller than the
physical network MTU in order to make room for tunneling overhead.

Note that the Puppet hieradata output in this change still needs to
be addressed in related Puppet changes, probably to both the Nova
and Neutron Puppet modules.

Change-Id: I38840e082ee01dc3b6fc78e1dd97f53fa4e63039
(cherry picked from commit 55e8f45fb12670f973c099c43fdbaff5b6ee66ff)

commit_message:
Add TripleO Heat Template Parameters for Neutron Tenant MTU

This change adds the TripleO Heat Parameters and Puppet hieradata
to support setting the MTU for Neutron tenant networks. A new
parameter, NeutronTenantMtu is introduced, and this gets used for
the NeutronDnsmasqOptions and in Puppet hieradata.

NeutronTenantMtu is also used in the Puppet hieradata for both the
compute and control nodes. Two values are set:

nova::compute::network_device_mtu

which sets /etc/nova/nova.conf: network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

neutron::network_device_mtu

which sets in /etc/neutron/neutron.conf:
network_device_mtu = <NeutronTenantMtu>

finally, the NeutronDnsmasqOptions parameter becomes a str_format
that maps the NeutronTenantMtu onto the DHCP options,
so a default of 'dhcp-option-force=26,%MTU%' would be formatted to
'dhcp-option-force=26,1300' if NeutronTenantMtu were 1300.

This will set dnsmasq to serve an MTU via DHCP that matches the
NeutronTenantMtu:

/etc/neutron/dnsmasq-neutron.conf:dhcp-option-force=26,1300

Typically, you would change all three of these settings to use small
or jumbo frames in VMs. When using tunneling, NeutronTenantMtu
should be set at least 50 bytes smaller than the physical network
MTU in order to make room for tunneling overhead.

Note that this change does not support setting the MTU on veth
interfaces if veth patches are used to br-int instead of OVS
patches.

Change-Id: I38840e082ee01dc3b6fc78e1dd97f53fa4e63039
(cherry picked from commit 55e8f45fb12670f973c099c43fdbaff5b6ee66ff)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/52/280852/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NeutronTenantMtu: description: > The default MTU for tenant networks. For VXLAN/GRE tunneling, this should be at least 50 bytes smaller than the MTU on the physical network. This value will be used to set the MTU on the virtual Ethernet device. This number is related to the value of NeutronDnsmasqOptions, since that will determine the MTU that is assigned to the VM host through DHCP. default: 1400 type: number neutron::agents::ml2::ovs::veth_mtu: {get_input: neutron_tenant_mtu} nova::network::neutron::network_device_mtu: {get_input: neutron_tenant_mtu} neutron_tenant_mtu: {get_param: NeutronTenantMtu}

commit_message:
Replace string format arguments with function parameters

There are files containing string format arguments inside logging
messages. Using logging function parameters should be preferred.

Change-Id: Id558f66de13146f6ae76a7a69f49721b6c3d6257
Closes-Bug: #1321274

puppet-prepare-node already took care of uninstalling the
puppet and facter packages that came preinstalled with the dsvm.
Hiera was not uninstalled and was shown to cause some issues when
attempting to use it.

Let's also uninstall hiera, it will be re-installed inside the jobs

Change-Id: I5e03d3de3c28afffb8dd30e429197eef02385520
"}]
commit_message:
Also purge the hiera package that comes preinstalled in dsvm

puppet-prepare-node already took care of uninstalling the
puppet and facter packages that came preinstalled with the dsvm.
Hiera was not uninstalled and was shown to cause some issues when
attempting to use it.

Let's also uninstall hiera, it will be re-installed inside the jobs
when installing the puppet package, it does not need to be
specified explicitely as it comes bundled with puppet now.

Change-Id: I5e03d3de3c28afffb8dd30e429197eef02385520
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/30/283830/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo yum -y remove facter puppet hiera rdo-release sudo apt-get remove -y --purge facter puppet puppet-common hiera
deleted_lines: sudo yum -y remove facter puppet rdo-release sudo apt-get remove -y --purge facter puppet puppet-common

commit_message:
Validate subs in api samples base class to improve error handling

Rather than passing subs around and risking bogus values or non-
existant keys, validate subs whenever it is updated to ensure
it conforms to the expected data types.

Implements bp:service-catalog-tng

Change-Id: I9480784d6852551c291c0c3e672216a5e9b48129

commit_message:
Added OS user account settings to openstack.yaml

This change introduces following attributes to openstack.yaml
- Operator User (part of group General/Operating System Access in UI):
  - name
  - password
  - home directory location
  - authorized SSH keys
  - sudo configuration
- Service User:
  - (hidden) name
  - (hidden) sudo
  - (hidden) homedir
  - (hidden) (generated) password
  - (hidden) (generated) Root password
This commit hides "Public key" setting from the UI as it
becomes redundant. It's going to be removed from other components
later.
"Access" group label has been changed to "OpenStack Access" as well
since that could be confusing.

Change-Id: I9074881191aa6279fdb3eb6abb1c86f6f3ecbb9f
Blueprint: fuel-nonroot-openstack-nodes
